loans.name: Cipriano

texts.en:
Cipriano, who is 55 years old, married to Gloria, and has two young children, completed a vocational course in photography and established a photography business to serve as his primary source of income. Providing services to weddings, birthdays and christenings, he usually earns about P30,000 monthly. Part of his income serves as revolving capital, while another part pays for the allowances and matriculation fees of his children.

Now requesting a loan of P10,000 to buy photo papers, film, albums and frames, Cipriano hopes to further develop his business and keep satisfying his customers.

loans.use: to buy photo paper, film, albums and frames for use in his photography service.

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
Avelina is 60 years old and has nine children, but some of them have their own family. Avelina was widowed 12 years ago. She says that being a single parent is very difficult, but Avelina does her best to meet their needs.  

She earns a living by planting and harvesting rice and selling it to traders in the Philippines. Avelina is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies. She works tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream and to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Handsuren

texts.en: Handsuren is 43 years old and lives with her mother and son in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Dornod province, Mongolia. Her mother is retired and her son is a college student. She started her garment retailing business in 2007 by renting space in the market. Her products are very fashionable and inexpensive therefore she has many regular customers. Now that her business is stable, she wants to expand her business by renting another space in the market. Handsuren is a hardworking and diligent woman who says"Since I am the only one with the income in the family, I have to pay my son's college fees". She is requesting 2,000,000 MNT to buy more garments from wholesalers in Ulaanbaatar, the capitol..

loans.use: To buy more garments for her clothing business.

loans.name: Chelu Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Chelu Group in Western Kenya!  Lucy is the facilitator of the Chelu group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Lucy takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Lucy had an excellent maize yield harvesting 20 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Lucy was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Lucy  and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Lucy will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Chelu group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Rubina's Group

texts.en:
Rubina, is young, 34, a kind and very responsible woman. She is married and has four children. She is happy with her children and husband by her side.  
Rubina’s work consists of sewing. Her work is home based.  She is well experienced in her business and financially contributes to the family from her earnings.  

Her husband is a vegetable vendor. He buys vegetables from the wholesale vegetable markets and sells to the customers. The quality and variety of his fresh vegetables increases demand among his clients. To improve his finances and serve the clients, Rubina is requesting for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah. Her husband will use the loan to buy seasonal vegetables in bulk, so he can sell them for a good price and increase his profits. 
She is hopeful that the loan investment will bring positive financial changes to her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy seasonal vegetables for a vegetable selling business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 28 year old married woman with one child of 6 years who is in school. Mary has had a food stall business in Kator South Sudan for eight yrs.
Mary has requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase onions and breads for sale. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase onions andbreads for sale.

loans.name: Altansuh

texts.en: Altansuh is 42 years old and lives with his wife and two kids in his own house in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. His wife is a disabled woman who stays at home. His elder son is a college student and the younger one is a school student. Altansuh started his business in 2000 by making furniture for nomads. Now his business is stable and he has many customers. Now that his product demand is increasing he needs to buy automated machinery to make his job efficient and more highly quality. He is a sharp and hardworking man who says "This year my son joined a college therefore, I need to work harder to pay his tuition". Altansuh is requesting 2,500,000 MNT to buy machinery.

loans.use: To buy machinery

loans.name: Nazaria

texts.en:
This is Nazaria, 53, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. . She is a widow and mother to her only child.  She manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.                             

Nazaria operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also offers a room for rent as an additional income. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 400 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Nazaria is requesting a Php 27,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Nazaria hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams of being be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Wekhonya B Shg Group

texts.en:
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Margaret and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Margaret is the facilitator of the Wekhonya B SHG group. The photograph shows Margaret with her group members. Standing on the far left is the field officer. Margaret and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Wekhonya B SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

Margaret joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Margaret had a very good maize yield harvesting 9 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Margaret was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on one acre of land. With income from maize sales, Margaret will educate her children and save for the future.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Rashida's Group

texts.en:
Rashida is a seamstress and sews clothes for her neighboring clients.  She is very skillful, creatively minded, and can prepare different designs of clothes.  She charges very reasonable rates to her clients.  Due to her quality work, she receives regular orders every month.
Her husband is a bus driver and provides transport services to his passengers.

Rashida has given birth to five sons. All of them are enrolled in local schools and are getting their education.
She has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for her husband who wants to change the tires on his bus.  This will allow him to drive his bus more smoothly and provide better transport services to his passengers.
He has been operating his business for many years and Rashida is hopeful that his income will be increased as a result of providing better customer service to his passengers by changing his bus tires.

loans.use: To buy new bus tires for a transportation business

loans.name: Buyanarvjih

texts.en:
Buyanarvjih is 33 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Umnugovi province, Mongolia. Her husband has his own van which he uses for transportation activities and the two children are school students. 

She started her sewing business in 1995. She moved to the center of the province and rented a counter in the market where her business is booming. She therefore needs professional sewing machinery and a large quantity of raw materials to meet the demand for products. She is a sharp and hardworking woman who says "I have done sewing for years however the income was not quite enough to support my family. Now that I moved to the center of the province, demand for my products is increasing and I am very excited about that". 

She is requesting 3,500,000 MNT to buy machinery and sewing materials.

loans.use: To buy machinery and sewing materials.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary, age 26, owns and operates a food stall business in Kator, South Sudan. She has run her business for the past year.

Mary has requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase onions, bananas, and tomatoes to offer for sale. She will use her extra income from this loan to save up money to build a house for her family sometime in future. She and her husband have three children between the ages of three and eight. They are all enrolled in school.

loans.use: to purchase onions, bananas, and tomatoes to offer for sale

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta, age 46, owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different home-use products to earn a living. She has been engaged in her business for 20 years. Each month, she earns PhP 5,000. She lives with her husband and childn in Ozamis, Misamis Occidental, Philippines.
 
She has requested a loan of PhP 30,000 to purchase products to offer for sale in her store. Julieta is been a member of GDMPC for three years. In the future, Julieta hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase products to offer for sale in her store

loans.name: Shirly

texts.en:
Shirly is 38 years old, married, and has two school-aged children.  Although Shirly is a member of BHW (Barangay Health Worker) still she ventures herself in the planting and harvesting of rice for sale to add to her income.  From this business, she is able to earn about P22,000 every harvest season.  She is grateful that her income allows her to help sustain the financial needs of her children and the families daily needs.  She dreams to lift her family from poor living conditions and that’s why she works hard through the family rice field.

At this moment, Shirly wants to receive a loan in the amount of P20,000 to buy rice seedlings, fertilizers, and insecticides for her rice field.  She hopes that she can get the amount she requested to further grow her business.

loans.use: to buy rice seedlings, fertilizers, and insecticides for her rice field.

loans.name: Busy Fingers Group

texts.en:
Ndaizivei, age 35, sells suits, costumes, jewelry, and shirts. She operates her business from her home and has been engaged in her business for three years. The challenge she faces is that sometimes business is slow and some of her debtors fail to pay on time. She is also involved in group activities with her lending group, whose members save and lend each other money. She is married and has two children, ages three and eight. Her husband is a teacher at a local school.
 
In the next five years, she wants to open a boutique in town. With the proceeds expected to result from the loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to better schools.

loans.use: to buy jewelry and suits to offer for sale

loans.name: Lucy Mkio

texts.en:
Lucy, age 39, sells soda to members of her local community. Her business is faced with the problem of low purchasing power from her clients. Lucy describes herself as honest and trustworthy. She and her husband have five children, aged between two and 15 years old. 
 
She will be using the loan Kes 20,000 to buy crates of soda to offer for sale.

In the future, Lucy wants to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy crates of sodas to offer for sale

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita makes herself busy all day long in her food selling business. Early in the morning, she cooks and prepares food for daily meals to sell. She cooks chicken and pork viands such as chicken curry, fried food and vegetable dishes to offer to her customers. Teresita's customers are mostly students. Her business is located near the school.

Teresita is now asking for a loan of P20,000 to buy pork and chicken meat, eggs, and soft drinks to use in her food selling business. She hopes to make her business more profitable despite the hardships encountered in her business. 

She has two children and hopes to educate them very well to earn a degree in order to improve their lives some day.

loans.use: to buy pork and chicken meat, eggs, and soft drinks to use in her food selling business

loans.name: Johna

texts.en:
Johna, age 31, earns a living by planting and harvesting rice to offer for sale. She has been engaged in this business for 10 years. Each month, she earns PhP 4,000 from her work. 

She has requested a loan of PhP 13,000 to purchase fertilizer, such as manure, for use on her farmland. Johna has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, Johna wants to make improvements to her house and to see her children complete their educations. Johna and her husband have two children and live in Pana-on, Misamis Occidental, Philippines.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, such as manure, for use on her farmland

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Vicky has been engaged in her rice farming business for eight years and earns about PHP 32,000 every harvest. She also has a sari-sari store (variety store), based in her home, from which she has been selling groceries for almost six months and earns PHP 800 daily. 

Vicky is willing to work hard every single day to lift her family out of poverty. According to her, through the income generated from her businesses she has been able to give daily allowances to her children, who are currently in school. At this time, she is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase seeds and fertilizers to sustain her rice field production. She hopes that she can get the amount she has requested to further develop her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers to sustain her rice field production.

loans.name: Abau

texts.en:
Abau is a 30 year old married woman with five children between the ages of 18 and 6. All of them are in school. She has had a business selling charcoal in Kator, South Sudan for two years.

Abau requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal. She will use the extra income she gets from this loan to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Loreza

texts.en:
Loreza is a married woman with two children. Loreza is 29 years old and resides in Dicoloc, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental: Philippines. 

Loreza owns and operates a farm, planting and harvesting rice to earn a living, and she's been in this business for seven years. Each month, she earns PHP 6,000 doing this type of business. 

She requested a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Loreza has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, Loreza wants to make improvements to her house and to finish the studies of her children.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Sabina is 49 and a resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Jesus, a sales man, and mother to her four children. Together with her husband and children, she manages the household while also operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Sabina operates a bamboo furniture business. She buys bamboo furniture from a local supplier and sells them at her store. She offers Sala sets, bed and tables made from bamboo. She displays her stocks of bamboo furniture in a vacant lot for customers to see. Aside from this she also operates a small variety store for added income.  Her customers usually come from the local community and nearby areas. She earns a minimum of PHP 3000 in profit every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a  PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy new stocks of bamboo furniture. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Sabina hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. Sabina faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of bamboo furniture needed in her business

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has been in the fish selling business in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last seven years.  He is 41 years old and married to Margaret. They have 4 school-going children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan amount to buy more stocks of fish for sale so as to sustain his business.

In the future, Peter hopes to expand his fish business to other markets in Ndunyu Njeru and neighboring towns and become the best fish seller in the region.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of fish for sale

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina is 39, married, and has three school-age children. With her husband, she plans to strengthen her family's sources of income in order to continue sending her children to school and give them a better future. Her income from her variety store is not sufficient to supply all their needs. Therefore, Josefina has decided to help her husband manage their corn farming business to ensure a high yield. 

Due to financial difficulty, she has asked for a loan PHP 35,000 to buy fertilizers and insecticides needed for the maintenance of their corn farming business. Josefina and her husband mentioned that this loan will help them to improve their business and they hope that they will have a fruitful harvest this coming harvest season.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and insecticides needed for maintenance of her corn farming business.

loans.name: Ma.luisa

texts.en:
Luisa is 50 and a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. Her husband is Bernardino, a watchman. Luisa is the mother of six children. Together with her husband and children, she manages the household while also operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.
                        
Luisa operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Luisa earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the item. She also offers a room for rent as an additional income source. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Luisa hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is a 31 year old married woman with four children between the ages of 12 and one. She has had a business selling tea in Kator, South Sudan, for two years.

Victoria requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase sugar and tea leaf. She will use the extra income she gets from this loan to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase sugar and tea leaf for sale.

loans.name: Kilimo Bora A Group

texts.en:
Florence joined One Acre Fund in order to have more food production and improve agricultural skills to ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Florence had a very good maize yield harvesting 17 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Florence was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on one acre of land. With income from maize sales, Florence will educate her children and save for future use.

Florence is the facilitator of the Kilimo Bora A group. The photograph shows Florence with her group members. Standing on the far left is the field officer. Florence and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Florence and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Elima

texts.en:
Elima has operated her beauty salon business in Naivasha town for the last six years.  She is 41 years old and single.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy more stock of cosmetics and beauty products for use in her salon.

In future, Elima hopes to expand her business by opening other beauty saloon shops in other areas of Naivasha tow. She also hopes to offer training to other people, and hence become a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: To buy more stock  of cosmetics and beauty products for use in her salon.

loans.name: Francis Omondi

texts.en:
Francis Omondi is 32 years old. He is married and has a six year old son. He describes himself as outgoing, generous and ambitious. He has been a mechanic for the last ten years. His business faces a problem due to the increased cost of spare vehicle parts. 

He will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy a bladder, a spray painting and a cutting machine. In the future, Francis wants to expand his business to neighboring towns and have more employees.

loans.use: To buy a spray painting and cutting machine and a bladder.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James has practiced farming in Naivasha town for the last nine years. He is 28 years old and married to Sebeki. They have two school-going children.  

He was introduced to KADET by one of our existing clients and this will be his second loan.  He paid all his previous loans well and on time. He plans to use the loan amount to plant potatoes in large scale as well as for irrigation purposes.

In the future, James hopes to become one of the leading large scale farmers in Naivasha town.

loans.use: to plant potatoes in large scale

loans.name: Hicela

texts.en:
Hicela is from the village of Caritan Centro, Tuguegarao City. She lives together with her spouse and two children. To make a living, she sells rice and Del Monte products such as pineapple juice and chunks. She offers her products at the market where sales opportunities are many. She usually makes about P3,000 each month.

She is now asking for a loan of P15,000 to buy more sacks of rice and Del Monte products to sell. 

She hopes to generate good income from her business and someday provide a succesfull life for her family.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of rice and Del Monte products to sell.

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en: Lucena is 57 years of age. She is thankful because she has been blessed with three children. Lucena is widowed for 13 years. She says that being single is very difficult but, Lucena makes her best to meet their needs. She is engaged in hog-raising business for 20 years and earns approximately PHP 8,000 every four months. She says that the most tiresome part is to clean the piggery every day. Aside from it, Lucena also engaged in her sari-sari store for two years for their additional income. She dreams to lift her family from poor living, that’s why she works hard through her businesses. She wants also to provide the necessities needed of her pigs, therefore she avail a loan amount P10,000 to buy feed, vaccine and vitamins for her pigs. She hopes this will make them fit and nourish to provide higher sales at disposing time, and she hopes to grow her business to secure her family living.

loans.use: to buy feed, vaccine and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 46 and a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. Her husband is Cesar, a driver. Marilyn is the mother of three children.  Together with her husband and children, she manages the household while also operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  
                          
Marilyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 9,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Marilyn hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice, age 22, has a charcoal-selling business in Kator, South Sudan. She has been engaged in her business for one year.

Joice requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal to offer for sale. She will use the extra income generated from this loan to buy a plot of land.

She and her husband have two children between the ages of two and five. The older child is enrolled in school.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal to offer for sale

loans.name: Mawa B Group

texts.en:
Alice takes care of five children at home.  In the recent 2011 season, Alice had an excellent maize yield harvesting 12 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Alice was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on ½ an acre of land. She joined One Acre Fund because of One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. With income from maize sales, Alice will educate her children, build a house and invest in business.

Alice is the facilitator of the Mawa B group. She is pictured in the photograph with her group members. Alice and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Mawa B group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Alice and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Isheanesu Group

texts.en:
Gloria, a member of the Isheanesu Group, is engaged in the flea market business. She sells such items as shoes, sandals, "tackies," skirts, dresses, jeans, and trousers. With her first Kiva loan, she increased her levels of inventory and her profits improved significantly as a result. Her family's well-being has improved through a better standard of living and an improved diet. 

In the near future she hopes to manage a bigger shop and to also operate her business with fewer liabilities.

loans.use: to buy clothing and footwear to sell at the flea market

loans.name: Weyeta Group

texts.en:
Rose takes care of six children at home. In the recent 2011 season, Rose had a good maize yield harvesting 8 ½ bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Rose was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on ½ an acre of land. She joined One Acre Fund because of One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family. With income from maize sales, Rose will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

Rose is the facilitator of the Weyeta group. Rose and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Weyeta group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Rose and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Kivikiyi Group

texts.en:
Evans takes care of nine children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food to ensure food security for his family and have additional maize profits to educate his children. In the recent 2011 season, Evans had an excellent maize yield harvesting 14 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Thomas was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on one acre of land. With income from maize sales, Evans will educate his children and save for medication for his child in the future.

Evans is the facilitator of the Kivikiyi group.The photograph shows Evans with his group members. The person standing on the far left is the field officer. Evans and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Kivikiyi group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Evans and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is an artist who crafts beautiful embroidered designs on clothes and also offers sewing services to her clients. She loves doing her work and tries to design new things to make each dress attractive. The demand for her services among her clients is very high and that is why she receives a good number of orders every month. Razia also prepares wedding dresses for her clients and generates good revenue from that. 

Razia has two children: one daughter and one son. Her son stays at home, while her daughter also operates an embroidery business to serve her family financially. Her husband is a driver by profession.
  
With this loan, Razia will purchase embroidery materials, such as beads, colored thread, and sketches, in bulk in order to prepare embroidered dresses and generate good profits. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy embroidery materials, such as beads, colored thread, and sketches, for her embroidery and sewing business.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta used her previous loan amount to buy wheat seedlings and fertilizer for planting during the planting season and it was very profitable. She paid all the loan amount well and on time. 

This will be her fourth loan and she plans to use the loan amount to plant wheat and potatoes. In the future, Jacinta hopes to have a large plantation of wheat and distribute wheat to wheat flour industries and other millers in the country.

loans.use: to plant wheat and potatoes

loans.name: Rhoda Njeri

texts.en: Rhoda is a married woman. She has 2 children with ages ranging from 3 years to 6 years. She describes herself to be ambitious and aggressive. Rhoda operates a retail store where she sells home products such as sugar,maize flour and  She has been involved in this business for 4 years. Her business is located in maua shopping centre. She describes her biggest business challenge as congestion in area of operation. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to pay rent and add stock of home products. Her business goal is to be a wholesaler and run more retail stores within 5 years.

loans.use: To pay for the rent and add stock of home products.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
As responsible parents, Mary and her husband would like improve their state of living to supplement their family's needs and educate their children. Despite the hardships of life, they continue managing their corn farming business to earn a living. They aimed to increase their yields and income to support the education of their two children. They want them to earn a degree so that they will be employed someday. 

Due to inadequate capital, she is asking for an additional loan of PHP 35,000 to buy fertilizers and pesticides needed for the maintenance of  their corn farming business. They believe that through their patience and hard work, they will improve their business and achieve their goal someday.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides needed for the maintenance of their corn farming business

loans.name: Tashinga Group

texts.en:
This is 40-year-old Hopewell from Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe.  He is married with four children, all of whom are still in school

Hopewell runs a agriculture business selling fruit and vegetables. The business has been in operation for 2 years. He says the main challenges he faces are the storage of perishable goods and competition. 

Hopewell has requested a loan of $400.00 to buy vegetables and fruit. He says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow him to improve the family's standard of living. In the future, Hopewell plans to open a grocery shop.

loans.use: To buy some fresh produce for sale

loans.name: Lulasi

texts.en:
Lulasi, age 50, earns her living by selling food items in Kator, South Sudan. She has operated her business for ten years.
 
Lulasi requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase groundnuts and breads to offer for sale. She will use the extra income expected from this loan to help pay the school fees of her four children, who are between the ages of five and 20 years old. Three of her children are enrolled in school.

loans.use: to purchase groundnuts and breads to offer for sale

loans.name: Joselito

texts.en:
Joselito is 32 years old and has three children. He is a chef in his own food stall. He cooks and prepares snacks to sell to the people in his village. He operates a food establishment which specializes in noodles, commonly known as a "panciteria." His food stall is located in front of his house. He has been operating his business for a year now.

He is now asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy pancit (noodles), onions, and eggs use in his food-selling business. He wants to improve his business and make it more profitable.

In the future, Joselito would like to earn enough income for the college education of his three children and someday lift his family out of poverty.

loans.use: to buy pancit (noodles), onions, and eggs use in his food-selling business

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa, age 44, oversees the operations of the tricycle transportation business she operates with her husband Bienvenido, who drives the vehicle and performs maintenance. They both manage their household while running their business. They have one tricycle unit that carries up to four passengers. For additional income, Luisa sells personal products.  

She lives with her husband and their child in GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She works hard to continually provide income for the everyday expenses of the family. Her regular customers are her neighbors and members of the local community. She earns a minimum of PhP 500 every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PhP 24,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan for maintenance of their motorcycle vehicle. 

She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business over the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members*, where she shares stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for the spare parts and maintenance of their motorized tricycle unit

loans.name: Hochi

texts.ru: Хочи является одной из пунктуальных и честных клиентов нашей организации, которая кредитуется в Арванде с 2007 года и каждый свой кредит использует целенаправленно для расширения бизнеса и получения хорошего дохода. Ей 53 года и она мать четверых взрослых детей. Её муж работает на насосной станции и его доход минимальный, всего 270 сомони или 55 долларов в месяц, поэтому бизнес приносит дополнительный доход для семьи. Прожиточный минимум у данной семьи на среднем уровне, по бизнесу ей помогает её младшая дочь Нигора. Её место деятельности  расположено на центральном рынке. В основном у неё свои постоянные покупатели на сумки, а также и клиенты уезжавшие в Россию. Которые покупают у неё чемоданы. На снимке Хочи у кассы в день выдачи, при получении кредита. На кредит в 1500 сомони она собирается завезти новые виды сумок и чемоданов. Она благодарна кредиторам и «Арванду» за понимание и своевременную поддержку ее бизнеса.
texts.en: Hochi is one of the punctual and honest clients of our organization, who has been obtaining loans from Arvand since 2007 and have used each of her loans purposely for business expansion and making good profits.  Hochi is 53 years old, and she is a mother of four adult children.  Her husband works at a pressure station and earns a minimum income of only 270 somoni or 55 dollars per month, and this is why the business brings in an additional income for the family.  The family has an average living minimum.  Hochi's youngest daughter, Nigora, helps her with the business.  Hochi's place of business is located among the rows of women's purses sales at the central Panshanbe market.  She primarily has loyal purse customers and also customers who leave for Russia and need to buy suitcases.  The photograph shows Hochi at the cash register on the day of loan disbursement.  She plans to use the 1500 somoni loan to bring in new types of purses and suitcases.  She is grateful to the creditors and "Arvand" for the understanding and timely support of her business.

loans.use: to expand the selection of purses and suitcases

loans.name: Altansuvd

texts.en:
Altansuvd is 42 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Gobisumber Province, Mongolia.  Her husband is an electrician, her elder son is a college student and her younger son is a student. Altansuvd started her meat retail business in 2004 by renting a counter in the market. She has many trusted suppliers and many regular customers. Now that winter is approaching, Altansuvd needs to save some meat supply before the price increases as it usually does. She is a sharp and hardworking woman who says, "Now that my son is a college student, I have to do everything I can to pay my son's college fees." 

Altansvud requests 2,500,000 MNT to purchase more meat that she can store because in the winter meat will be less available.

loans.use: To purchase more meat to store because meat is less available in the winter.

loans.name: Salomat

texts.ru:
Саломат, женщина 50-ти лет, которая с 2002 года сотрудничает с Арвандом. В начале своей деятельности Саломат торговала женским нижним бельём, и оборот её бизнеса был небольшой. Ассортимент товаров тоже был невелик. Муж Саломат работает поваром в столовой и его доход полностью идет на семейные расходы. К тому же один из сыновей клиентки находится на заработках в России, и каждый месяц присылает им денежные переводы на проживание. Саломат год за годом увеличивала свой товарооборот при получении очередного кредита и на полученные доходы выдала замуж дочь, отремонтировала свой дом. За девять лет кредитной истории Саломат ни разу не нарушила условия организации. Она за это время сменила своё место деятельности, на сегодняшний день арендует контейнер на большом вещевом рынке «Сомон» и её товарооборот увеличился в несколько раз. А также повысилось и улучшилось социальное и семейное положение.
Свой новый кредит Саломат собирается употребить на закуп сезонных товаров.
texts.en: Salomat is a 50 year-old woman, who has been working with Arvand since 2002.  At the beginning of her entrepreneurial activity, she sold women's undergarments and had a small business turnover.  The selection of goods was also limited.  Salomat's husband works as a cook at a cafeteria, and his entire income gets used for family expenses.  Also, one of the client's sons works in Russia and sends them money for living expenses every month.  Salomat has been increasing her good turnover year after year with the help of the loans and used the resulting profits to marry off her daughter and repair her house.  Over the nine years of credit history, Salomat has not once violated the terms of the organization.  Over this time, she changed her place of business and today leases a container at the large clothing market, "Somon," and her goods turnover increased several fold.  And also their social and family condition increased and improved.  Salomat plans use her new loan to purchase seasonal merchandise.

loans.use: to purchase seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy 200 chicks for her poultry business and three 50 kg sacks of matemba to sell.

loans.name: Marhabo

texts.ru: Мархабо мать четырёх детей, которой 51 год и она уже более десяти лет торгует на рынке детской одеждой и обувью. В Арванде она кредитуется уже более 4 лет. Торгует Мархабо на рынке Паншанбе в центре города Худжанда. В начале своей деятельности активы ее бизнеса составляли всего 600 долларов, а на сегодняшний день её товарооборот развернулся до 2000 долларов. Если раньше она завозила товар из оптового рынка Истаравшана, то теперь за товаром ездит её младший сын в соседний Кыргызстан, город Бишкек. Ассортимент ее товаров стал разнообразным и качественным. Старший её сын на заработках в России, который стабильно высылает деньги родителям для семейных расходов, и Мархабо старается все доходы вкладывает в свой бизнес. При погашении своих кредитов пунктуальна, так как порядочная женщина. На 5000 сомони Мархабо планирует привезти зимний детский товар, а также и зимние сапожки  и ботинки.
texts.en: Marhabo is 51 years old and is a mother of four children.  She has been selling children's clothing and shoes at a market for over ten years.  She has been obtaining loans from Arvand for over four years.  Marhabo works at the Panshanbe market in the city center of Khujand.  At the beginning of her entrepreneurial activity, her business assets amounted to only 600 dollars, and today her goods turnover expanded to 2000 dollars.  She previously brought in the merchandise from the wholesale market in Istaravshan, and now her youngest son travels for the merchandise to the city of Bishkek in the neighboring Kyrgyzstan.  Marhabo's goods selection became more varied and quality.  Her oldest son works in Russia and consistently sends money to the parents for the family expenses, and Marhabo tries to invest all of the profits into her business.  She is punctual with repaying her loans because she is decent woman.  Marhabo plans to use 5000 somoni to bring in winter children's merchandise and also winter boots and shoes.

loans.use: to purchase winter children's merchandise and also winter boots and shoes

loans.name: Amka Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Amka Group in Western Kenya! With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Felistus and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Felistus is the facilitator of the Amka group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
In 2012, the members of Amka group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Felistus takes care of six children at home. In the recent 2011 season, Felistus had an excellent maize yield harvesting 16 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Felistus was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on one acre of land. Felistus joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. With income from maize sales, Felistus will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mwembula Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Mwembula SHG Group in Western Kenya! 

Ruth takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Ruth had a very good maize yield harvesting 20 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Ruth was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on one acre of land. With income from maize sales, Ruth will educate her children and save for the future.

Ruth is the facilitator of the Mwembula SHG group. The photograph shows Ruth with her group members. Standing on the far left is the field officer. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Mwembula SHG group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Ruth and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Munenga Group

texts.en:
Julius is the facilitator of the Munenga group. Julius and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. He is the father of four children. He joined One Acre Fund to have additional maize profits to educate his children and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Julius had a good maize yield harvesting 8 bags on 3/4 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Julius was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on 3/4 acre of land. With income from maize sales, Julius will educate his children and build a house. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Julius and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. In 2012, the members of Munenga group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land. Julius is pictured with his group members in the photograph.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Tomas

texts.en:
Tomas is from Cabatuan, Isabela. He is the proud father of two school-aged children. Tomas helps to support his family through their family rice field. Tomas is known for being a hardworking and honest person. He is married to a business-minded woman who has helped him to manage their family rice field for 15 years. His wife also manages their sari-sari store for extra income. 

At this time, he would like a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy fertilizers and seedlings for his farm business. According to his plan, this investment will increase his income in addition to helping his children. Even though life is difficult, he enjoys being a farmer living in the Philippines.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seedlings for his farm business

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia, 49, resides in GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Eddie, who is also her business partner.  With her husband, Alicia manages the household and operates their business.  She works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Alicia operates a food stall. In the Philippines, workers and most families only eat home-cooked meals in the evening because it is the time when all of the family members are home. This is not only a family tradition, but also a matter of convenience and frugality. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one or two people when it costs less to buy cooked rice and meat.  In addition to her food stall business, Alicia sells homemade snacks and pork meat for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 600 Philippine Pesos (PHP) every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she requests a PHP 39, 000 loan. She will use the loan to buy additional supplies of necessary items, like meat, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasoning. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Alicia hopes to grow her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase the ingredients and products needed for her food stall business.

loans.name: Kunthea's Group

texts.en:
Kunthea,36, is married and has four children, all of whom are in primary school. She is a farmer in a rural area of Kangmeas District.  Kunthea has been farming for 12 years to earn a living. Also, she does some cultivation on her farmland. Sometimes she works for others to generate additional income, earning $1 per day for her labor. In total, she earns less than $5 per day to feed her six-member family.

This loan is Kunthea's first with Kiva partner VisionFund Cambodia. She leads a group of four female members and is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer for her rice field and crop seeds to plant on her land. 

Kunthea hopes this loan will enable her to increase her crop yield and earn more income to feed her family.  She also hopes to build some savings to keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy crop seeds and fertilizer for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Kang Meas district

loans.name: David Gitimu

texts.en:
David is a married man with three children between the ages of 6 months and12 years old. He describes himself as ambitious.  David operates a retail store where he sells electrical goods. He has been involved in this business for six years. David says his biggest business challenge is the high cost of electrical goods. 

David will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy electrical goods. His business goal is to run more electrical retail stores within the next five years.

loans.use: To add stock of electrical goods to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy 200 balls of wool to knit jersey and three buckets of matemba to sell.

loans.name: Otabek

texts.ru: Отабек занимается выращиванием и продажей сельскохозяйственных культур. Кроме этого он занимается выращиванием крупного и мелкого рогатого скота. Отабек является владельцем данного бизнеса и ему помогает брат и жена. Семь лет назад он начал свой бизнес с купле- продажи мелко рогатого скота, а теперь хочет продолжить свой бизнес и расширить его. Отабег хотел бы получить займ в размере 4500 Сомони для покупки минеральных удобрений для переработки земли и покупки мелкого рогатого скота.
texts.en: Otabek grows and sells agriculture crops. He also grows large and small horned cattle. Otabek is the owner of this business and his brother and wife are helping him. He started his business seven years ago with buying and selling of small horned cattle and now wants to continue his business and expand it. Otabek wants to get a loan in the amount of 4,500 somoni to buy mineral fertilizer for processing of land and buy small horned cattle.

loans.use: to buy mineral fertilizer and cattle.

loans.name: Bayambadorj

texts.en: Bayambadorj is 33 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent, in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. His wife works at a water supply company. Byambadorj operates transportation service business using his own truck. He started his business in 2000. He transports firewood and coal between provinces and Ulaanbaatar. Byambadorj's transportation service business income is pretty much the same since he started the business. With his business profits he is buying construction materials to build his own house. He is requesting 2,600,000 MNT to buy more wood and coal to deliver and to increase his income with coming new year.

loans.use: To buy more wood and coal

loans.name: Hyline Kerubo

texts.en:
Hyline Kerubo is 27 years old and single. She runs a grocery store where she sells fruit and vegetables.  Her business faces the challenge of inadequate capital to purchase additional produce stock. 

Hyline will use the KES 15,000 loan to buy more fruit and vegetables for sale. In the future, she wants to run a restaurant and sell fish.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Winifreda

texts.en:
Winifreda, 61, is a resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is a widow and a mother. She manages her household while also operating a business. She works hard to continually provide income for her family's everyday expenses.

Winifreda operates a business where she buys general merchandise from wholesalers and then sells the items for a small profit. Her products are children’s clothes, ready-to-wear clothing and other similar items. Customers are attracted to buy from her because of her low prices and the many options she offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) every day.

To help her continue her business operations, Winifreda requests a PHP 20,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy ready-to-wear clothing and other merchandise to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Winifreda hopes to be able to expand her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies with the group.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase ready-to-wear clothing and other merchandise to increase her business inventory.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 27 years old and married to her husband, John.  They have one child who is six months old.  Esther has sold second-hand clothes for the last three years and earns an income of KES 6,000 a month.

This is her first loan from Kiva partner KADET LTD.  Esther will use the entire loan to buy more clothes for sale.  She will use the anticipated profits to provide for her family's basic needs.  Esther hopes to grow her business and open a boutique in future.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale.

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
To earn a living, Beverly and her husband help each other in managing their corn farming business to increase their yields. They endure the hardships and difficulties they encounter in life because they want to improve their state of living and give their children a bright future. They aim to increase their yields so that they will earn a higher income and finance the education of their children.

She is requesting a loan of PHP 25,000 to buy farm materials like fertilizers and pesticides for the maintenance of their corn production business. She and her husband believe this loan will help them to make an improvement in their business, and they hope they will have a plentiful harvest.

loans.use: to buy farm materials like fertilizers and pesticides for the maintenance of her corn production

loans.name: Musalaba F.a Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Musalaba F. A. Group in Western Kenya! 

Philisters takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, she had a good maize yield harvesting 9 bags on 1/2 an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, she was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on 1/2 an acre of land. With income from maize sales, Philisters will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing. 

Philisters is the facilitator of the Musalaba F. A. group. She is pictured with her group members. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Musalaba F.A. group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Philisters and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Kilimo Bora B Group

texts.en:
Joseph is the facilitator of the Kilimo Bora B group. Joseph and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Joseph and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Joseph takes care of seven children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and grow enough food to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Joseph had an excellent maize yield harvesting 17 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Joseph was only able to harvest 12 bags of maize on one acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Joseph will save for the future and educate his children.

In 2012, the members of Kilimo Bora B group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph, Joseph is pictured with his group members and the field officer is standing on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Madine

texts.fr:
Madame MADINE est une femme âgée de 40 ans qui vit avec ses 5 enfants et son époux dans une famille nucléaire à N’TJIBOUGOU, un des quartiers de la ville de SANANKOROBA, préfecture de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro(deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
MADINE n’a pas avancé dans les études  pour des raisons familiales,  alors très tôt elle s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat vente d’articles divers  tels les habits, les pochettes, les chaussures, les parures,  etc. 
Après avoir correctement remboursé les  prêts précédents, MADINE est à son quatrième prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, quelques douzaines d’habits pour enfants et 50 paires de chaussures de différentes sortes, auprès des grossistes du marché de BAMAKO. Elle effectue sa vente à la maison, au  marché de SANANKOROBA et en ambulant dans les différents quartiers de la ville, en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Madame MADINE espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, aider le mari à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités. 
MADINE ambitionne diversifier davantage ses activités et devenir grossiste en habillements et chaussures à SANANKOROBA
texts.en:
Madine is a 40-year-old woman who lives with her five children and her husband in a nuclear family in N'Tjibougou, one of the districts of Sanankoroba, in the Kati prefecture of the Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Madine did not continue her schooling for family reasons, and early on became interested in income-generating activities, in particular the retail trading of miscellaneous items such as clothes, bags, shoes, jewelry, etc.

Having successfully repaid the previous loans, Madine is on her fourth individual loan. She intends to use it to buy a few dozen children's clothes and 50 pairs of shoes of different kinds, from wholesalers in the markets of Bamako. She performs her retail sales from her home, at the Sanankoroba market, and as an itinerant vendor through different parts of the city, for cash and credit to both men and women customers.

Madine hopes to achieve an average monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA she will use to repay the loan, help her husband deal with family expenses and reinvest the rest in her business activities.

Madine aims to further diversify her activities and become a wholesaler of clothing and shoes in Sanankoroba.

loans.use: Buy clothes and shoes

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane, who describes herself as ambitious, has run a retail shop for two years. The business faces a challenge in that it is constantly necessary to increase the stock of goods. Jane will be using the loan Kes 20,000 to add inventory to her store. She looks forward to expanding the business in the next five years.

Jane is married and has a one-year-old baby daughter.

loans.use: to add inventory to her store

loans.name: Msamaria Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Msamaria Group in Western Kenya! Rose is the facilitator of the Msamaria group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Rose takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Rose had a good maize yield harvesting 14 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Rose was only able to harvest 11 bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Rose and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Rose will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Msamaria group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Batsuren

texts.en: Batsuren is 38 years old and lives with his wife and son in a ger (Mongolian yurt/ nomadic tent) in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. His wife is a clerk and his son is a school student. He started his hairdressing business in 2006 by renting a space in the market. Now (in 2011) that his business is stable, he also has started to operate a barber shop. He also rented a counter in the market to sell cell phones which is right next to his hairdressing place. His new business seems to be highly profitable. He is a sharp and hardworking man who says "I can manage two business at once and I don't like to miss an opportunity. This business is already paying off and I want to expand it by selling a broader range of products". He is requesting 2,000,000 MNT to buy phone supplies and cell phones.

loans.use: To buy phone supplies and cell phones

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy three bags of maize.

loans.name: Lim's Group

texts.en:
Lim, age 52, is the leader of this group of two borrowers. She started farming on her farmland 15 years ago to earn a living. She also maintains a cow that she utilizes as labor for plowing. Sometimes she shreds coconut meat to offer for sale in order to raise additional income. 

Lim and her husband live in a rural area of Prey Chhor district. They have raised four children. Three are employed at a garment factory and one is a construction worker. 

This is Lim's second group loan wI. VisionFund. She has completed repayment on her first loan wI. VisionFund and is now requesting a loan to buy rice seeds for her farmland. She hopes to plant and harvest rice and sell it at a good price. Her goal is to build on her savings for the family's future needs.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Djeneba

texts.fr:
Madame DJENEBA est une femme âgée de 28 ans qui vit avec ses 2 enfants et son époux dans une famille nucléaire à BELE, un des quartiers de la ville de SANANKOROBA, préfecture de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro.
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école,  alors très tôt elle s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat et à la vente d’habits, mèches et prestation au niveau d’un salon de coiffure.
DJENEBA est à son premier prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, des douzaines d’habits pour enfants et pour femmes,des cartons de mèches et l’entretien de son salon de coiffure, auprès des grossistes à Bamako et quelques fois au marché de SANANKOROBA auprès de forains. Elle effectue sa vente à la maison et aux marchés de SANANKOROBA, au salon, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Madame DJENEBA espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 45.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, aider le mari à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités. 
DJENEBA ambitionne diversifier davantage ses activités et devenir grossiste  en habillements SANANKOROBA
texts.en:
Madame Djeneba is 28 years old. She lives with her husband and two children in a nuclear family in Bele, a neighborhood of the city of Sanankoroba, in the Kati prefecture in the Koulikoro region.

Not having had an opportunity to attend school, at a young age she became interested in revenue generating activities such as buying and selling clothes and hair extensions, and providing hairdressing services.

This is Madame Djeneba's first individual loan, which she intends to use for the purchase of children's and women's clothing, boxes of  hair extensions, and cleaning products for her hairdressing salon from the wholesalers in Bameko and the stallholders in Sanankoroba market. She sells her products from her home, at the Sanankoroba markets, and from her salon, for cash or credit, to a clientele including both women and men.

Madame Djeneba hopes to make an average monthly profit of  45,000 FCFA, which she will use to repay the loan and to help her husband with the household expenses. She will invest the remainder in her business. 

Her ambition is to diversify her business activities and to become a clothing wholesaler in Sanankoroba.

loans.use: to purchase various items.

loans.name: Buyant

texts.en:
Buyant is 37 years old and lives with his wife and two kids in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. His wife helps with his business while the elder child goes to school and younger one goes to kindergarden. 

Buyant started his garment retailing business in 2008 by renting a counter in market. He also is a part time taxi driver. Now that winter is approaching, he needs winter supplies to sell. He is requesting 3,500,000 MNT to buy mass a amount of winter clothes.

Buyant is a sharp and hardworking man who says "my kids are growing and they will go to college someday, so I need to act aggressively in order to be able to pay for their college fees."

loans.use: to buy a mass amount of winter clothes

loans.name: Anoga

texts.fr:
Aniga est une femme âgé(e) de 48 ans. Elle est mariée å un  inspecteur de douanes. Elle a 01 enfant de 23ans qui est scolarisé.
Aniga travaille comme restauratrice depuis 2009. Elle vend dans un restaurant après achat à Lomé. Sa difficulté est la concurrence sur le marché.
Aniga a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des boissons. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Aniga voudrait agrandir l’activité. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit avoir une famille heureuse.
texts.en:
Anoga is 48 years old. She is married to a customs officer and has one 23-year-old child, who is educated.

Anoga has been a restaurateur since 2009 and her biggest challenge is the competition from other restaurateurs. She gets the supplies for her restaurant in Lomé. She is requesting her first loan from WAGES so that she can restock on drinks for her business.

In the coming years, Anoga would like to expand her business and plans to use her profits to make her family happy.

loans.use: to buy drinks for her restaurant.

loans.name: Joseph Gitonga

texts.en:
Joseph is married and has two children who are ages of five and seven years old. He has been selling shoes for four years at Kangeta shopping centre in Maua town.The business is faced with the problem of increased costs of maintaining the business. 

Joseph will be using the loan Kes 20,000 to buy shoes. He wants to expand his business in the future and add stocks of shoes.

loans.use: to add stocks of shoes.

loans.name: Sheywe Farmers Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Sheywe Farmers Group in Western Kenya! Peter is the facilitator of the group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Peter takes care of seven children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, he had a good maize yield harvesting nine bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Peter was only able to harvest two bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Peter and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Peter will ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Sheywe Farmers group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize. He is pictured with his group members in the photograph.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
Reynaldo is 40, married and has six school-age children. Due to lack of job opportunities, he engages in vegetable production to earn a living and support his family. As a responsible father, he wants to continue sending his children to school so that they will earn a degree and one day, find a good job. 

Although farming is a difficult occupation his strong determination to be successful means he can endure hardships and pursue his business.

Due to financial constraints, he is requesting additional capital of PHP 18,000 to buy the pesticides he needs to maintain vegetable production. 

He believes this loan will enable him to improve the business and ensure a good harvest. He hopes that his patience and hard work will make his dream a reality.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides needed for the maintenance of his vegetable production business

location.town: Bitnong Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Friends Shg Group

texts.en:
Samuel takes care of two children at home. In the recent 2011 season, Samuel had an excellent maize yield harvesting 12 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Samuel was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on ½  acres of land. He joined One Acre Fund because of One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. With income from maize sales, Samuel will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

Samuel is the facilitator of the Friends SHG group. Samuel and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Friends SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Samuel and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Umoja A Group

texts.en:
Ben takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to secure food for his family and to have farm inputs in time for planting. In the recent 2011 season, Ben had an excellent maize yield harvesting 8 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Ben was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on ½ an acre of land. With income from maize sales, Ben will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing and his business to save for future use.

Ben is the facilitator of the Umoja A group. The photograph shows Ben with his group members. The field officer is standing on the far left. Ben and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Umoja A group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Ben and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012.
