Since September 2, 2008, she has been a member of the “banc villageois,” where she sits as president.  Soda is part of the Ande Liguey solidarity group and she works in sales, specifically selling fresh fish.

With her new loan of 400,000, she is going to purchase 40 baskets of fish, which she will then sell retail in her neighborhood market.

She will use her profits to purchase rice, oil and sugar, and to pay for school supplies for her children.

loans.use: to purchase fresh fish for retail sale

loans.name: Umoja B Group

texts.en:
Handa is the facilitator of the Umoja B group. Handa and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Handa and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Handa takes care of one child at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to have additional maize profits to send his child to school and secure enough food for his child. In the recent 2011 season, Handa had an excellent maize yield harvesting 18 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Handa was only able to harvest three bags of maize on one acre of land.

With income from his maize sales, Handa will educate his child and save in business and livestock rearing for future use.

In 2012, the members of Umoja B group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph, Handa is pictured with his group members. Standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Amani Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Amani Group in Western Kenya! Rhoda is the facilitator of the Amani group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Rhoda takes care of one child at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Rhoda had an excellent maize yield harvesting 18 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Rhoda was only able to harvest four bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Rhoda and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Rhoda will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Amani group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Khurshedjon

texts.ru: Хуршедджон занимается выращиванием сельскохозяйственных культур. Он выращивает овощи и  продает на местном рынке. Ему в бизнесе помогает жена и брат. Они вместе дружно работают. Каждый имеет свои обязанности. Хуршедджон хочет расширить свой бизнес и получить хорошую прибыль на улучшение семейных условий. Хуршедджон запрашивает займ для покупки минеральных удобрений и ядохимикатов для переработки земли.
texts.en: Khurshedjon works in agriculture. He grows vegetables and sells them at the local market. His wife and brother help him in this business. They work together amicably; each has their own responsibilities. Khurshedjon wants to expand his business and make good profit in order to improve his family's livelihood. He is applying for a loan in order to purchase mineral fertilizers and pesticides for his plot of land.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fetilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Ronnie

texts.en:
Ronnie is a farmer in his community.  At the age of 44, he has operated this kind of business for 10 years.  He is managing a corn field where he can earn about P40,000 every harvesting season.  Compared to other farmers, he put the least amount of income into his business.  He was not able to provide for the needs of his business, and the consequence was to earn little.

For this reason, he is asking for a loan in the amount of P15,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides.  He could then care for his business and see it return to an abundant income generator.  He hopes that through this loan amount and his hard work, his business will start to be successful.  By then, he hopes his five children will finish their studies and gain degrees.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides.

loans.name: Bakyt

texts.ru:
Бакыт 27- летний фермер, женат, имеет одного ребенка. С детства Бакыт был включен в семейное фермерство, что и стало основным источником дохода и для его собственной семьи. С 2003 года Бакыт начал заниматься откормом и перепродажей скота, вложив при этом начальную сумму в 23,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорству и настойчивости в стремлении обеспечить достойную жизнь своей семье, Бакыт работал не покладая рук. На сегодняшний день, его ферма с коровами и баранами успешно развивается, принося ежемесячный доход в сумме около 20,000 сом (KGS) от продажи молочных и мясных  продуктов. 
Для дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Бакыт обратился в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку бычков для откорма. Доходы от кредита он планирует направить на  закуп стройматериалов для постройки нового сарая для скота.
texts.en:
Bakyt is a 27 year old farmer, he is married with one child. Since childhood Bakyt was included in the family farm, which was the main source of income for his own family. Since 2003 Bakyt started fattening and selling cattle with an initial investment amount of 23,000 som (KGS). Because of the tenacity and perseverance in the quest for a decent life for his family Bakyt worked tirelessly. Today, his farm with cows and sheep is developing successfully and brings a monthly income of about 20,000 som (KGS) from the sale of meat and dairy products.

For further development of his business Bakyt has turned to Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan in the amount of 100,000 KGS for the purchase of bulls for fattening. He plans to use the proceeds from the loan in a purchase of construction materials to build a new barn for the livestock.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Rey

texts.en:
Rey is 24 years old, a farmer, married, and blessed with one child.  To support his family, he patiently works in the field every day.   He doesn't feel his tiredness in working the field because of his child that serves as his inspiration.  He pursues his work in order to provide a better future for his family.

With his net income of P30,000 every harvesting season, he suffers insufficiency because of the high price of farm inputs.  The profit is not enough for his business, let alone if he add his families expenses.  This caused him to ask for a loan in the amount of P15,000 to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides needed in his farming business.  Through this loan, he would be able to provide the necessities to his farm and return to a high net income.  In this case, he would then save for the future of his family.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides.

loans.name: Sinoko Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Sinoko Group in Western Kenya! Elizabeth is the facilitator of the Sinoko group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Elizabeth takes care of one child at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Elizabeth had a poor maize yield harvesting 10 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Elizabeth was only able to harvest two bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Elizabeth  and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Elizabeth will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Sinoko group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mukunduzi A Group

texts.en:
Julius is the facilitator of the Mukunduzi B group. Julius and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Julius and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Julius takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to have additional maize profits to send his children to school and secure enough food for his children. In the recent 2011 season, Julius had an excellent maize yield harvesting eight bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Julius was only able to harvest four bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With income from his maize sales, Julius will educate his children and save in business and livestock rearing for future use.

In 2012, the members of Mukunduzi B group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph, Julius is pictured with his group members and standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Alasseni

texts.fr:
Monsieur ALASSENI est né en 1974 à KADIOLO. Père de cinq enfants vivant dans une famille traditionnelle à Kaï, préfecture de Kadiolo.
 Il mène cette activité de commercialisation de céréales depuis 4 ans. Son expérience dans ce domaine, lui a valu une bonne réputation et reçoit des commandes de céréales, notamment du maïs. Ainsi pour avoir les ressources nécessaires afin de satisfaire ces clients, il collabore avec l’Institution de Micro Finance Soro Yiriwaso, il ya 5 cycles maintenant, les prêts passés ont été correctement dénoués.  
Ce prêt lui permettra d’acheter 2 tonnes de maïs et 1/2 tonne de mil. Il s’approvisionne dans les villages avoisinants de Kaï. Les céréales sont stockés dans son magasin. Il  les revend au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes venant de SIKASSO et de BAMAKO. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 80 000 FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
 Il compte devenir un grossiste de bonne renommé à fin de satisfaire ses nombreux clients qui ne cessent de croitre
texts.en:
Mr. Alasseni was born in 1974 in Kadiolo. He is the father of five children all living in a traditional family in Kai, part of the Kadiolo prefecture.

He has been trading in cereals for four years. His experience in this area has earned him a good reputation and he is getting orders for cereals, especially maize.

To ensure he has the necessary resources to satisfy his clients, he has been working with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, where he has already completed five loan cycles, all of which were properly settled.

This loan will enable him to buy two tons of maize and a half-ton of millet. He gets his supplies from villages in the vicinity of Kai. The grain is kept in his storeroom, and then resold for cash to both men and women customers coming from Sikasso and Bamako.

He expects this loan will produce average monthly profits of 80,000 FCFA. The profits will enable him to pay off loan interests and invest the remainder into his business activity.

He intends to become a renowned wholesaler to satisfy an increasing number of customers.

loans.use: Buy cereals

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en:
Nestor, 50 years of age, is married and has two children. The family lives in Cauayan City, Isabela where Nestor generates income by planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has more than 31 years of experience in farming and is able to earn PHP 25,000 with each crop. Nestor's wife has a business raising hogs for their additional income.

The income from their businesses helps Nestor and his wife to cope with the family's needs. Nestor wants to obtain a loan in the amount of PHP 10,000 to buy farm supplies such as fertilizers and corn seedlings. He hopes that he can get the amount requested to further the growth of his business.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies such as fertilizers and corn seedlings

loans.name: Fazliddin

texts.ru: Фазлиддин женат и ответственный отец пятерых детей. Он хочет содержать свою семью в хороших жизненных условиях. Он знает что работа на земле всегда приносит доход , поэтому он занимается выращиванием сельхозкултур. Более двух лет Фазлиддин выращивает лук и зерно. Фазлиддин запрашивает займ для покупки минеральных удобрений, ядохимикатов и оплаты труда работников.
texts.en: Fazliddin is married and a responsible father of five children. He wants to maintain his family in good living conditions. He knows that the work on the land always brings profit so he is engaged in cultivation of crops. Fazliddin has been growing onions and corn for more than two years. Fazliddin is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides and pay his employees for work.

loans.use: to purchase of fertilizer, pesticides, and to pay for hired labor.

loans.name: Lassine

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Lassine a 34 ans, marié et père de cinq enfants, il réside avec sa famille à Hamdallaye Extension, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso. 
Monsieur Lassine après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié au domaine du transport, en devenant un chauffeur de profession disposant de son propre engin un camion “REMORQUE”, et aux activités d’achat et de ventes d’articles divers tels des matériel électroniques. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses appareils. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de  collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant trois ans. Il effectuait. Il est à son cinquième prêt individuel, tous ses quatre prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 Avec ce cinquième prêt, il compte acheter une importante quantités de matériels électroniques casses de différentes sortes( radios, téléviseurs, montres, appareils de sonorisation). Il s'approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes au Ghana, Togo et Bénin, avant de les revendre en détail.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour  contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Lassine is 34 years old, married with five children, and resides with his family in Hamdallaye Extension, one of the working-class areas in the city of Sikasso.

Having attempted several activities without success, Mr. Lassine initiated himself into the transportation sector, becoming a professional driver with his own tractor-trailer vehicle, and started a trading business of various items such as electronic equipment. He is much in demand by his clients for the quality of his offerings.

To satisfy a constantly growing number of customers, he decided three years ago to work with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution. He is now on his fifth individual loan, and his four previous loans have all been properly reimbursed.

With this fifth loan, he intends to purchase a large quantity of broken-down electronic equipment of varied nature (radios, televisions, watches, audio equipment). He buys from wholesale traders in Ghana, Togo and Benin, before reselling retail.

He expects this loan to generate monthly profits of 250,000 FCFA, to be used primarily in helping with family expenses, paying loan interests and investing in the business.

loans.use: Buy broken-down electronic equipment

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo is 28 years old.  Because he only finished his elementary education, he works as a farmer, raising corn. He does not blame his parents for what happened to him; instead he accepts it. He is thankful that he was raised working in their farming business, and today he patiently works as a farmer. Alfredo is married and blessed with three children. He has own family to support, so in order to avoid repeating what happened to him, he works hard in his business to provide a better future for his children.

Working hard is not enough to operate a farming business; it also requires funds to purchase necessities, such as fertilizer. Therefore, Alfredo is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 from Alalay sa Kaunlaran (ASKI), Inc. He will use it to buy seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides. Hopefully, he will earn a higher income in return for his efforts.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides.

loans.name: Zulfiya

texts.ru: Зулфия проживает в Яванском районе. Ей 48 лет. Она замужем. У нее двое детей. Ее муж работает в России. Сама Зулфия занимается разведением мелко - рогатого скота. Этим видом деятельности она занимается восемь лет. Кредит берет для закупа скота.
texts.en: Zulfiya resides in the region of Yavan. She is 48 years old, married and has two children. Her husband works in Russia. Zulfiya is engaged in breeding small horned cattle. She has been in this business for eight years. She is taking out the loan to purchase cattle.

loans.use: to buy two calves.

loans.name: Tajy Poty Group

texts.es:
10 mujeres de la ciudad de Villa Ygatimi se ha unido con el propósito de ayuda por medio de su trabajo en conjunto. Ellas ven en el programa de la fundación paraguaya una gran ayuda para ellas mismas y para sus familias.Actualmente se encuentran en el segundo ciclo, del programa de comités de mujeres emprendedoras, desean llegar al nivel máximo.
Ana es una de las miembros, ella se dedica a la venta de prendas de todo tipo, comenta que este ha sido su trabajo hace ya un buen tiempo, que gracias a esto ha logrado formarse ya una clientela bien definida, lo que le trae muy buenos ingresos. Por eso quiere seguir invirtiendo en su negocio por lo que solicita el crédito.
Desea comprar prendas para abastecerse y cumplir con la demanda de sus clientes, quiere comprar remeras, shorts, camisillas y demás tipos, con lo cual podrá cumplir con la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Ten women from the city of Villa Ygatimi have joined together with the goal in mind of helping each other through teamwork.  They see in Fundación Paraguaya’s program a great help for themselves and for their families.  They are currently in their second cycle in the enterprising women program and they want to reach the next level.

Ana is one of the members.  She sells all types of clothes and she comments that this has been her work for quite some time now and thanks to this she’s been able to secure a good, regular clientele that produces good income for her.  Because of this she wants to continue investing in her business and this is why she’s requesting a loan.  She wants to buy clothes to stock up and meet customer demand.  She wants to buy t-shirts, shorts, undershirts and other types to meet customer demand.

loans.use: to buy clothes for subsequent resale.

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Née vers 1964 à Sikasso, Madame Aminata est mariée et mère de huit enfants, elle vit chez son époux avec ses enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Mancourani I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, elle s’est initiée depuis plus de  vingt ans à cette activité génératrices de revenus. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation dans cette activité de vente de condiments, qui a lieu, à la maison et au marché de Mancourani I dont elle dispose une place.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cessait d’accroitre, elle décida ainsi de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ 2 années. Après 2 prêts individuel tous correctement remboursés, elle est à son troisième prêt individuel  qui lui permettra d’augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter  5 seaux de pâtes d’arachides, 4 cartons maggie, 3 cartons concentrée de tomate,  3 sacs d’oignons et 3 cartons de moutarde, à Sikasso 
Madame Aminata vend  au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de toutes les couches sociales. 
 Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 95 000 FCFA qui sera utiliser pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born around 1964 in Sikasso, Aminata is married and mother to eight children. She lives with her husband and children as part of a large traditional family in Mancourani I, one of the popular neighborhoods of the town Sikasso (the third administrative region of the republic of Mali).

After having managed several businesses without success, she started this business which generates revenue over twenty years ago. She enjoys a good reputation in this business selling condiments, both from home and in the Mancourani I market where she has a stand. Wanting to satisfy her clientele which kept growing, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso approximately two years ago. After two individual loans both correctly reimbursed, she is on her third individual loan which will allow her to expand her business by purchasing five buckets of peanut paste, four cartons of maggie, three cartons of tomato concentrate, three bags of onions and three cartons of mustard, in Sikasso.

Selling to customers from all sectors of society, Aminata accepts both cash and credit. With this loan, she envisages making a profit of 95 000 FCFA which she will use to contribute to family expenses, pay the interest on her loan and reinvest the rest in her business.

loans.use: to buy condiments

loans.name: Pio

texts.en:
Pio is 58 years old and has worked as a farmer for 15 years. He must work in the fields to support his one child. His farm is the primary source of income for meeting all of their everyday expenses, such as allowances.

Due to the high price of food, the family is short on funds, so Pio needs financial assistance to operate his business. He is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers, and insecticide. These farm inputs would be a big factor in improving his corn field. Hopefully, by next season, he will earn enough profit from his harvest to improve his business as well as the family's overall standard of living.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, and insecticide.

loans.name: Pablo

texts.en:
Pablo is 30 years old, an industrious husband and father. He is blessed with one child. To support his family, he has built and manages a cell phone accessories and repair shop. His business also provides jobs to two employees who repair cell phones. In order to pay them, he needs to upgrade his service as well as his profit. 

Pablo is requesting a loan of PHP 40,000 to buy quality cell phone accessories and cell phone materials. He will save additional income for his parents and especially his family.

loans.use: to buy cell phone accessories and materials.

loans.name: Anahit

texts.ru:
Анаит 49 лет; она родилась и выросла в городе Каджаране, а сейчас проживает в городе Капане. 
Анаит замужем и у нее двое детей: сын и дочь. Муж Анаит работает руководителем одной из Капанских обшин, сын учится на четвертом курсе  Капанского политехнического института, а дочь вышла замуж и сейчас живет в Ереване. 
С 2008 года  Анаит занимается частным предпринимательством: продает женскую, мужскую одежду и обувь. Раз в два месяца Анаит сама ездит в соседнюю страну и приобретает товары для своего бизнеса. Анаит работает без выходных и у нее много постоянных клиентов. Анаит всегда очень дружелюбна со своими покупателями и всегда помогает им советом, если есть такая необходимость. Благодаря своему бизнесу, Анаит помогает мужу содержать семью и платить за обучение сына. 
Анаит необходим кредит на сумму 500.000 армянских драмов для приобретения пальто, зимних курток и сапог для своего бизнеса.
texts.en:
Anahit is 49 years old, she was born and raised in Kajaran and now lives in the town of Kapan. Anahit is married and has two children, a son and a daughter. Her husband works as a head at one of Kapan's municipalities, her son is in the fourth year of Kapan Polytechnic Institute, and her daughter got married and now lives in Yerevan.

Since 2008 Anahit has been running her own business: selling women's and men's clothing and shoes. Anahit goes to the neighboring country once in two months and purchases goods for the business. Anahit is working seven days a week and she has many loyal customers. She is always very friendly with her customers and always helps them with advice if needed. Through this business Anahit helps her husband to support their family and pay for their son's education.

Anahit needs a loan in the amount of 500,000 drams to purchase coats, winter jackets and boots for her business.

loans.use: to buy coats, winter jackets and boots for her business.

loans.name: Makerita

texts.en:
Makerita, age 55 and widowed, is a farmer. Her primary income is derived from planting and harvesting taro for sale. Makerita has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 720 WST a month from these activities. She lives in the town of Neiafu Uta with her two school-aged children.  

Earlier this year, Makerita joined SPBD* to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Makerita is requesting her first loan from SPBD in the amount of 1,000 WST, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Mafanikio Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Mafanikio Group in Western Kenya! Nancy is the facilitator of the Mafanikio group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Nancy takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Nancy had an excellent maize yield harvesting eight bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Nancy was only able to harvest 1 1/2 bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Nancy and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Nancy will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Mafanikio group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.en:
Gregorio is 34 years old, married, and blessed with three children. He is an industrious husband and father. After over 10 years in this business, it seems that progress is very hard for him to make. Almost all of his profits go to traders and even just a daily allowance is really difficult for him to provide.

Due to these challenges, he decided to ask for assistance from Alalay sa Kaunlaran Inc. (ASKI) in the form of a loan of 15,000 PHP. The loan will be used to purchase corn seeds, pesticides, and fertilizers. The difficulty of farming doesn’t stop him from pursuing this life, especially now that he has ASKI as his partner in improving his business and his family's living conditions. He hopes that he will be able to earn for his family instead of for traders.

loans.use: to purchase corn seeds, pesticides, and fertilizers.

loans.name: Pulumatau

texts.en:
Pulumatau, age 49, is a taro farmer. Her primary income comes from planting and harvesting taro and offering her produce for sale. Pulumatau has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 640 WST a month from these activities. She is married and lives in the town of Neiafu Uta. She and her husband have raised three children, now grown.  
 
Earlier this year, Pulumatau joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Pulumatau is requesting her first loan from SPBD in the amount of 1,000 WST, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment.  

Pulumatau plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Né en 1966 à Sikasso, Monsieur  Daouda est marié et père de six enfants, il réside avec sa femme et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Fama un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso
Monsieur Daouda est un réparateur de profession des moulins depuis plus de dix huit. Aussi il dispose de son propre moulin pour ses prestations et il mène en parallèlement à son métier, l’achat-vente des pièces détachées et des moulins casses. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a maintenant une année et avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
 Il compte acheter avec ce premier prêt,  5 moulins casse à farine, 5 moulins casse à décortiqueuse et des pièces de rechanges. Ces moulins casses seront détachés en pièces  sur place à travers leurs démontage  pour être vendues par pièces dans son atelier.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 95 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt
texts.en:
Born in 1966 in Sikasso, Daouda is married with six children. He lives with his wife and children in a large traditional extended family in Fama, a working-class neighborhood in Sikasso.

Daouda has worked at repairing mills for more than eighteen years.  He also has his own mill, and along with his repair work, he buys and sells broken mills and spare parts for mills. He is much sought after by his customers for the quality of his products.

In order to satisfy his ever increasing clientele, one year ago he decided to join the micro-finance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he is obtaining his first individual loan.

With this loan, he intends to buy five broken flour mills, five broken huller mills and spare parts. These broken mills will be dismantled on site so that the parts can be sold in his workshop.

As a result of this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 95,000 FCFA, which he will use to increase his business capital, contribute to the family's expenses and pay the interest on the loan.

loans.use: to buy broken mills and spare parts.

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander is from the village of Gulebi, West Georgia. He is 62 years old and lives with his family--his wife, Narguli, and two sons who are 26 and 27 years old. Narguli works as a nurse in a local hospital, and their sons work for a local road service company. 

Alexander manages the agricultural business of the family, which is the main source of income for them. He grows various fruits and vegetables on 1.2 family-owned hectares of land and sells harvested products to local retailers. Also, the family has two milk cows. Narguli and Alexander produce cheese and sell it locally. The total average monthly income of the family is 1000 Laris. 

Alexander requested credit for purchasing nut and persimmon tree seedlings. The demand for nuts and persimmons is always high at the local market. After a couple of years, the family will sell additional products and increase their income. They will use their increased income for purchasing additional household goods to improve family living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase nut and persimmon tree seedlings.

loans.name: Zikir

texts.ru: Более 16 лет Зикир занимается купле- продажей продуктов питания. Он продает сахар, макароны, рис, разные виды сладостей и овощей. Ему в бизнесе помогает сын. Зикир хочет расширить свой бизнес и получить хорошую прибыль. Зикир запрашивает займ для покупки продуктов питания с целью увлечения ассортимент продуктов. Он надеется на вашу помощь и заранее благодарен вам.
texts.en: Zikir has been in the business of buying and selling of food for more than sixteen years. He sells sugar, pasta, rice, different kinds of sweets and vegetables. His son helps him in the business. Zikir wants to expand his business and make a good profit. He is requesting a loan to buy food to expand the variety of products. He looks forward to your help and thanking you in advance.

loans.use: to buy food products.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad, age 43, has worked as an electrician for 20 years. His extensive experience has brought him the trust of his customers and has provided him with the ability to provide specialized services that are highly requested at any time. Sadly, however, the income from this business is not stable, and since his family requires a consistent income, Mohamad started an extra business: a grocery store. He reports that it has provided much of the stability he had hoped for it to provide for his family. 

To improve both businesses, Mohamad is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmou, in order to buy necessary tools for his electrician business in addition to adding more products to his grocery store. He expects an increased income in both areas as a result of this loan.

Mohamad is a man with a very good reputation both as an electrician and as a grocer. He is very highly respected by his customers.

loans.use: to buy necessary tools for his business

loans.name: Kadiatou

texts.fr:
Kadiatou a plus de 49 ans mariée et mère de sept enfants, elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Sanoubougou I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso.
Kadiatou après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité de commercialisation des  céréales (riz, mil) il y a environ  14 ans. Elle dispose d’une place au marché de Sanoubougou I à Sikasso. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro et elle est actuellement à son premier prêt individuel
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 10 sacs de riz et 10 sacs de mil. Elle achète  les céréales auprès des grossistes de Sikasso avant de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes de ménages et des chefs de famille.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Kadiatou is over 49 years old. She is married with seven children, and lives with her husband and their children in a traditional extended family in Sanoubougou I, one of the working-class districts of the city of Sikasso.

After conducting many unsuccessful activities, she started marketing cereals (rice, millet) about 14 years ago. She holds an emplacement at the Sanoubougou I market in Sikasso.

To better serve an ever-increasing number of customers, she decided to join the Soro micro-finance institution and is currently on her first individual loan.

She intends to use the loan to buy 10 bags of rice and 10 bags of millet. She buys grain from wholesalers in Sikasso before selling it retail to a customer base of mostly housewives and heads of household.

She expects this loan to generate a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA, to be used primarily in helping with family expenses, paying interest on the loan and investing the rest into her business activity.

loans.use: Buy grain

loans.name: Alan

texts.en:
Alan is 33 years old, married and blessed with two children. His primary source of income comes from farming. With five years of experience in this business he can say that it is a difficult occupation, because it always seems that he is walking in the dark and does not know where to go. He says so because farming requires a lot of patience, hard work, optimism and – of course – funds. Farmers do not know from one season to the next if they will be able to make a profit or not, because potential calamities that might destroy their precious farms are always looming on the horizon.

Despite the precarious nature of farming, Alan is very optimistic about operating his business. He is asking for a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy corn seeds, pesticides and fertilizers, all of which could be a great help in yielding abundant crops, which is why he is pursuing the loan.  He is prepared to work hard in return for this opportunity. He is hoping for good crops for the sake of his family’s welfare.

loans.use: to buy corn seeds, pesticides and fertilizers

loans.name: Liua Isapela

texts.en:
Liua-Isapela, age 29, is a farmer. Her primary income is derived from from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables to offer for sale. Liua-Isapela has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 1,200 WST a month from her work. She and her husband have one school-aged child.

In 2010, Liua-Isapela joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Her purpose was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Liua  has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,000 WST from SPBD.  This previous loan was used to purchase seedlings and sacks of fertilizer.  

Liua-Isapela is now requesting a new loan of 1,450 WST which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. The loan will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Liua-Isapela plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her family house.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Lassina

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Lassina  est âgé de 48 ans marié et père de quatre enfants. Il est domicilié à Wayerma I à Sikasso dans une famille traditionnelle élargie.
Lassina après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initié à cette activité de stockage et commercialisation des céréales (maïs, mil, sorgho) il y a maintenant trois ans. Il dispose d’un magasin au grand marché de Sikasso en face de la BDM SA. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec il est à son cinquième prêt individuel , tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Il compte avec ce cinquième prêt  acheter,  25 sacs de maïs et 25 sacs de mil et 10 sacs de sorgho en provenance des localités environnantes de Sikasso. 
Ces marchandises sont d’abord stockées dans son magasin afin d’êtres revendues en gros à une clientèle composée des détaillants et des chefs de famille.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt
texts.en:
Mr. Lassina is 48 years old and married with four children. He lives in a traditional extended family in Wayerma I, Sikasso.

After attempting many unsuccessful activities, Lassina started three years ago a business trading and storing grain cereals (maize, millet, sorghum). He has a store at Sikasso's great market in front of the BDM SA.

In order to better serve his ever-increasing customers, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution. He is now on his fifth individual loan, all previous loans having been properly reimbursed.

He intends to use this fifth loan to buy 25 bags of maize, 25 bags of millet and 10 bags of sorghum in the communities surrounding Sikasso. These goods are first stored in his shop to be resold wholesale to a client base of retailers and heads of households.

He expects this loan to generate a monthly profit of 150,000 FCFA that will be used primarily to increase his business assets, contribute towards family expenses and pay interest on the loan.

loans.use: Buy grain

loans.name: Fuaifatu

texts.en:
Fuaifatu is a 30-year-old woman living in the town of Samata I Uta.  She is married and has one school-aged child.  To make a living, Fuaifatu owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector growing crops.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting taamu for sale.  Fuaifatu has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 800 WST a month from these activities.

In 2010, Fuaifatu joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Fuaifatu has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1000 WST from SPBD.  This previous loan was used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment.  Fuaifatu is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment.  The loan will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Fuaifatu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to the borrower's house.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies and equipment.

loans.name: Silongeloa Group

texts.en:
Joy is the facilitator of the Silongelo A group. Joy and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Joy and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Joy takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to secure food for her family and to have additional maize profits to send her children to school. In the recent 2011 season, Joy had an excellent maize yield harvesting 22 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Joy was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on one acre of land.

With income from her maize sales, Joy will invest in livestock rearing and educate her children.

In 2012, the members of Silongelo A group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

Joy is pictured with her group members. The person standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Kuña Pyapy Mbarete Group

texts.es:
El comité Kuna Pyapy Mbarete tiene el total D. 14 integrante . Son mujeres trabajadoras y muy responsables formaron su grupo entre vecinas y amigas y ya hacen parte del Comité D. Mujeres Rurales D. la Fundación Paraguaya. Ellas se encuentran muy felices trabajando dentro D. la fundación por lo que les gustaría poder llegar al nivel máximo del programa.
Berta es una mujer muy sacrificada y trabajadora, ella es una mujer que lucha por el sustento D. su familia, ya que desea darles lo mejor, puesto que no quiere que ellos pasen por las mismas privaciones que ella. Comenta que se dedica a la cría y posterior venta D. animales, como ser gallinas y cerdos. Le va muy bien con su trabajo, por lo que le gustaría poder seguir creciendo. Una D. sus metas es llegar a tener una granja llena D. animales.
Solicita la ayuda D. fundación paraguaya y D. kiva para la compra D. animales pequeños y alimentos para estos.
texts.en:
The Kuna Pyapy Mbarete communal bank has 14 members. The members are hardworking and very responsible women who are neighbors and friends. This group makes up part of Fundación Paraguaya’s Rural Women Communal bank (Comité D. Mujeres Rurales). They are very happy be working in the foundation because they would like to reach the highest level of the program. 
Berta is a very sacrificing and hardworking woman. She is a woman who fights to support her family in order to give them the best. She does not want them to deal with the same hardships she has had. She raises and sells animals like chickens and pigs. Her work is going very well and she would like to continue growing the business. One of her goals is to have a farm full of animals. 
She is requesting help from the Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva to purchase small animals and food for those animals.

loans.use: buy small animal and food for those animals.

loans.name: Mahamadou

texts.fr:
Né en 1985 à Sikasso ville, Monsieur Mahamadou  est marié et père de 2 enfants il réside avec sa femme et ses enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle avec ses parents et ses frères à Sikasso.
Après l’activité de boulanger sans succès, Mahamadou s’est initié il y a deux années à la vente de matelas en provenance de Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso). Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a une année.  Il a bénéficié deux prêts  tous correctement remboursés, ainsi il sollicite un troisième afin d’augmenter son fonds de commerce.
 Ce troisième prêt lui permettra ainsi d’acheter 15 matelas d’épaisseur 15, 8 matelas d’épaisseur 20 “deux places” et 10 matelas d’épaisseur 20 “trois places”. Il est très sollicité surtout par les menuisiers-ébénistes de la ville. Ses matelas sont vendus en détail au comptant et souvent à crédit.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born in 1985 in Sikasso City, Mr. Mahamadou is married with two children. He lives with his wife and children in a traditional family along with his parents and his brothers in Sikasso.

After unsuccessfully trying his hand as a baker, Mahamadou started two years ago selling mattresses coming from Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso). To satisfy the increasing number of his customers, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution a year ago.

He was granted two loans, both of which were correctly repaid, and he is now requesting a third loan to increase his business assets.

The third loan will enable him to purchase fifteen 15-cms-thick mattresses, eight two-person 20-cms-thick mattresses, and ten three-person 20-cms-thick mattresses. He is much in demand especially by furniture makers from the city. His mattresses are sold retail, for cash and often on credit.

He expects this loan to generate monthly profits of 120,000 FCFA that will serve mainly to help with family expenses, pay interest on the loan, with the rest being reinvested in his business activity.

loans.use: To buy mattresses

loans.name: Feliza

texts.en:
Feliza is 52 years old, married, and has three children. She and her family live happily in a village and have a plan to raise their standard of living. Farming is one of their major sources of income; they plant and harvest corn for sale. They have been in this business for more than thirty-five years and usually earn a profit of PHP 30,000 in each harvest season. 

At this time, Feliza is asking for a loan of PHP 30,000 to buy corn seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides, and to pay for the labor needed for corn-planting. She and her family believe that this loan will be an enormous help to their hopes of increasing their yield.

loans.use: to buy corn seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides, and to pay for the labor needed for corn-planting.

loans.name: Nofo

texts.en:
Nofo is a 40-year-old woman living in the town of Satuiatua.  She is married and has three school-aged children.  To make a living, Nofo owns and operates a business venture in the food sector running a bakery.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from baking and selling a variety of confectionaries such as cookies and cakes in the local community.  Nofo has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 1000 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Nofo joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Nofo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1500 WST from SPBD.  This previous loan was used to purchase baking equipment.  Nofo is now requesting a new loan of 1900 WST which will be used to purchase a new oven, baking powder and sacks of flour.  The loan will be the fourth loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Nofo plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase a new oven, baking powder and sacks of flour.

loans.name: Lavenia

texts.en:
Lavenia is a 43-year-old woman living in the town of Sagone.  She is married and has four adult-aged children.  To make a living, Lavenia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector growing crops.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale.  Lavenia has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 800 WST a month from these activities.

In 2011, Lavenia joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Lavenia is requesting, for the first time, a loan from SPBD.    Lavenia is now requesting a new loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment.  The loan will be the first loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Lavenia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies and equipment.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a married man with five school going children. He lives in a rental house with electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food for his family and school fees for his children. 

James has operated a vegetable stall for the past three years and his potential clients are his neighbors. He faces a major challenge of seasonality. He dreams of expanding his business.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase more stock of tomatoes, potatoes, cabbages and onions for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access funds to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of tomatoes, potatoes, cabbages and onions for resale.

loans.name: Fakhriddin

texts.ru: Фахриддин проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 45 лет. Женат, имеет четверых детей. Двое его сыновей находятся а Российской Федерации. Сам он имеет среднее образование. Зарабатывает путем разведения крупнорогатого скота. Два года как занимается этим видом деятельности. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Fakhriddin lives in the region of Yavan. He is 45 years old. He is married and has four children. His two sons are in the Russian Federation. He has secondary education. He makes a living by breeding large horned cattle and has been in this business for two years. He is taking out the loan to purchase cattle.

loans.use: to buy large horned cattle.

loans.name: Sériba

texts.fr:
Né  à Tinzanadougou préfecture de Sikasso, Monsieur Sériba est marié et père de 7 enfants, il réside avec ses deux épouses et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Sériba après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié au domaine de vente de bétail il y a environ 9 an. Il mène cette activité au marché de bétail du nouveau marché de Médine où il vend des moutons, chèvres, etc. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de son bétail. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son deuxième prêt individuel 
 Il sollicite ainsi ce deuxième prêt individuel pour acheter 20 petits ruminants dans les localités environnantes qui sont entre autres (Bamoukou, Kléla, Koro Barrage, etc.) lui permettant de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante.
 Avec ce prêt il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born in the Tinzanadougou Prefecture of Sikasso, Mr. Sériba is married with seven children. He lives with his two wives and their children in a traditional extended family in Sanoubougou I, one of the working-class districts in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

After conducting several unsuccessful activities, Mr. Sériba introduced himself to selling livestock about nine years ago. He conducts this activity in the livestock section of the new Medina market where he sells sheep, goats, etc. He is much in demand by his clients for the quality of his livestock.

To satisfy his increasing number of customers, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution where he is on his second individual loan cycle.

He is requesting this second individual loan to buy twenty small ruminants from communities in the surrounding area (among others Bamoukou, Kléla, Koro Dam, etc..). This will enable him to better serve his growing number of customers.

He expects this loan to generate a monthly profit of 150,000 FCFA to be used primarily in dealing with family expenses and paying loan interest. The remainder will be invested in his business activity.

loans.use: Buy sheep and goats

loans.name: Mankanay

texts.ru: Манканай 54 года, замужем, воспитала двоих детей.  Манканай  во время Союза работала дояркой в колхозе,  а ее муж – комбайнером. После развала советской системы колхозов, Манканай с мужем решили заняться откормом и перепродажей скота.  Начатое еще в 1995 году с суммы в 20,000 сом (KGS) хозяйство сегодня приносит около 10,000 сом (KGS) в месяц от продажи молочных  и мясных продуктов. Также, на собственной земельной доле Манканай выращивает кормовые сельхозкультуры для животных, что позволяет ей экономить на  закупе корма для скота. В целях дальнейшего увеличения поголовья скота, Манканай обратилась в компанию «Бай  Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 125,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дополнительного скота. Доходы от кредита Манканай планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение количества домашней скотины.
texts.en: Mankanay is 54 years old, married, and has raised two children. During the Soviet times, Mankanay milked cows at a collective farm, while her husband operated a combine harvester. After collective farms ceased to exist, Mankanay and her husband decided to start their own farm, raising and selling animals. They started out in 1995, with 20,000 KGS, and today their farm brings in 10,000 KGS per month from sales of dairy and meat. Also, Mankanay grows various crops for the animals on her own land, allowing her to save money on feed. With the goal of increasing the number of heads of cattle on her farm, Mankanay has turned to Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan of 125,000 KGS, to purchase additional animals. Income from the loan will be used to expand her farm.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Naponi

texts.en:
Naponi is a 35 year old married woman with four children between the ages of 16 to 4 years, and all of them are in school. She has had a business selling tea in Kator, South Sudan for two years.

Naponi requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase sugar. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the school fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase sugar for resale.

loans.name: Yaya

texts.fr:
Monsieur Yaya a 39 ans, marié et père de deux enfants, il réside avec sa famille à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso.
Monsieur Yaya après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié au domaine du commerce il y a environ quatre ans  et  il dispose d’une quincaillerie au grand marché de Sikasso. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, il est à son premier prêt individuel.
 Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter 10 boîte de colle, 15 cartons baquette, 15 paquets de peinture, 50mètres de fil, 5 pelles, 5 piquaches, etc . Il s'approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes à Bamako avant de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des constructeurs de maison (architectes, entrepreneurs, maçons, etc.).
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Yaya is 39 years old. Married with two children, he resides with his family in Sanoubougou I, one of the working-class districts of Sikasso.

After unsuccessfully trying his hand at several activities, Mr. Yaya became involved in retail commerce about four years ago, and operates a hardware store at Sikasso's great market. He is much sought after by his clients due to the quality of his products.

To satisfy his expanding customer base,  he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution. This is his first individual loan.

With this first loan he plans to buy 10 boxes of glue, 15 cartons of welding sticks, 15 packages of paint, 50 meters of wire, 5 shovels, 5 pickaxes, etc. He buys from Bamako wholesalers before reselling in detail mainly to a customer base of homebuilders (architects, contractors, masons, etc.).

He expects this loan to generate monthly profits of 150,000 FCFA, that will be used primarily in dealing with family expenses and paying loan interests. The remainder will be invested in his business activity.

loans.use: To purchase hardware store items

loans.name: Salohidin

texts.ru: Салохидин женат и имеет пятерых детей. Он занимается выращиванием сельскохозяйственных культур. Он выращивает овощей. Салохидин хочет расширить свой бизнес и хочет получить хорошую прибыль на обеспечении своих детей.  Ему в бизнесе помогает супруга и дети. Салохидин запрашивает займ для покупки минеральных удобрений и ядохимикатов для переработки земли.
texts.en: Salohidin is married with five children. He is engaged in the cultivation of agricultural crops. He grows vegetables. Salohidin wants to expand his business and wants to ensure a good return for his children. His wife and children help him in his business. Salohidin is asking for a loan in order to purchase mineral fertilizers and pesticides for the processing of his land.

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Muzira Twimukye Group

texts.en:
Coffee earns the Ugandan economy more foreign exchange than any other export. It has been Uganda's main cash crop since time immemorial.
Ugandan families that have been partial to the idea of coffee farming have had their chequered share of fortunes. Many Ugandans though, grumble about the fact that the for-ex that the country earns from coffee has not been trickling down to the lowest common denominators in terms of service provision.
Nonetheless, many Ugandan families have been able to extricate themselves out of their narrow circumstances, principally by selling most of their coffee harvests to the many coffee marketing unions in the country.

One of these Ugandans is 33 year old Lauben, who plys his trade in Bushenyi in the West of Uganda. Lauben says the fact that he is now able to sell his coffee to the more lucrative coffee unions in Rwanda has given his business a Substantial boost.

The lusty, buoyant and hard working father has 5 years experience in this trade. Weekly he says his sales returns total up to Ugandan shillings 60,000. He says he intends to utilize his loan to purchase more coffee seedlings to plant.

loans.use: to purchase more coffee seedlings to plant

loans.name: Arsen

texts.en:
Arsen lives in the village of Dimi, West Georgia. He is 35 years old, married and lives with his family: his wife, Tamar, and his seven-year-old son, one-year-old daughter and 70-year-old mother. All of the adult family members are involved in the family farming activities. They have three milk cows and three calves. Tamar produces cheese and sells it on the local open market. The family also has a pig and sells an average of 12 piglets per year. The total average monthly income of the family is 1,000 laris, including Arsen's mother's pension. 

Arsen has requested credit to purchase an additional milk cow. The family will be able to increase their cheese production and sales by at least 30%, and this will increase the income of the family. They will use the additional income to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase an additional milk cow.

loans.name: Lala Lemou

texts.fr:
Madame  LALA LEMOU a 47 ans, réside avec son époux et leurs sept enfants à Noumousso, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Kadiolo.
LALA LEMOU  fait la commercialisation de boubous en bazins  et d’encens il y a environ 11 ans. Elle mène son activité dans sa famille au quartier Noumousso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée par sa clientèle à cause de la qualité de ses produits et de sa crédibilité. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle a sollicité l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Son prêt lui permettra d’acheter  une vingtaine de pièces de bazins (riche – moins riche), une dizaine de kilogrammes de graines de “magnon kisenin - gueunnin” et 15 bouteilles de parfums à Bamako. Après teinture et couture des bazins en  boubous ils sont  vendus. De même que les graines et parfums après transformation sont vendus. Elle les vend au comptant et à crédit à Kadiolo à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes à domicile et de façon ambulante.
Elle envisage réaliser avec son prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 70 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé en grande partie pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Lala Lemou is 47-years-old and lives with her husband and their seven children in Noumousso, one of the popular neighborhoods in the town of Kadiolo.

Lala Lemou has been marketing boubous [long, loose-fitting African garments] made from bazins [colorful fabrics with designs on them] and incense for about 11 years. She manages her family business in the Noumousso neighborhood where she is much in demand by her customers because of the quality of her products and her credibility. 

To meet the demands of her growing clientele, she has appealed to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso.

Her loan will allow her to buy around 20 pieces of bazin ("rich" [100% pure cotton] to "less rich" [not 100% cotton]), around 10 kilograms of "magnon kisenin - gueunnin" seeds and 15 bottles of perfume in Bamako. After dying and sewing the bazins into boubous they are sold. Similarly the seeds and perfumes are processed and then sold. She sells both from home and as a street vendor in Kadiolo, accepting both cash and credit from a clientele consisting of men and women. 

She envisages making an average monthly profit of 70 000 FCFA which will be used mostly to expand her business, contribute to family expenses and pay the interest on her loan.

loans.use: to buy a variety of items

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en: Maribel has been engaged in her corn-farming business for twenty years, and she usually earns PHP 25,000 per crop. She is willing to work hard every single day to lift her family out of poverty. She is married to a farmer who helps her manage their farm. According to her, through the income generated from her business, she has been able to give daily allowances to her children, who are currently in school. She is now requesting a loan of PHP 25,000 to purchase seeds and fertilizers to sustain her corn farm’s production. She hopes that she can get the amount she requested so she can further develop her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers to sustain her corn farm’s production.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is applying for another loan to start a new poultry selling business. She will use this 100,000 Kes loan to purchase chicks and chicken feed for her new poultry business. In the future, Pauline aspires to continue improving her businesses. 

Since taking her last Kiva loan, Pauline has greatly improved her family’s standard of living. She hopes to continue accessing the financial services offered by Yehu and Kiva lenders and thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase chicks and chicken feed for her new poultry business.

loans.name: Daraja Mbili Group

texts.en:
David is the facilitator of the Daraja Mbili group. David and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

David takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, David had a good maize yield, harvesting 9 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  David was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to David and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, David will educate his children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Daraja Mbili group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Né vers 1980 à Koutiala,  ADAMA  est un homme marié et père de six enfants, qui vit avec sa famille à Loulouni, une des  sous préfecture de la 3eme Région Administrative (Sikasso) du MALI.
  ADAMA   mène cette activité de restauration avec la vente de café et vente de biens de consommation, il y a environ six ans. Il jouit d’une forte réputation dans cette activité et reçoit beaucoup de clients surtout les jours de foire de Loulouni, mais ses ressources ne peuvent pas lui permettre de les satisfaire. C’est ainsi, qu’il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son quatrième prêt , les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
Il compte acheter avec son prêt  du sucre, du café, du lait, des œufs, du beurre français et des paquets d’ articles de boutique. 
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utiliser pour  assurer l’essentielle de ses dépenses, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born 1980 in Koutiala, Adama is a married man and father of six children. He lives with his family in Loulouni, one of the sub-prefectures of the third administrative region (Sikasso) of Mali.

Adama has worked in the food industry for about six years, selling coffee and consumer goods. He has a good reputation in this business and serves many clients, especially on Loulouni fair days, but he does not have sufficient resources to satisfy them all.  That is why he decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso. He is on his fourth loan, the previous ones having been properly reimbursed.

With this loan, he intends to buy sugar, coffee, milk, eggs, French butter and packets of items for the store.

He hopes to make a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA, which he will use to cover his essential expenses and pay the interest on his loan. He will invest the rest in his business.

loans.use: to buy various items.

loans.name: Munyofwe Women Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth is the facilitator of the Munyofwe Women group. Elizabeth and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Elizabeth and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Elizabeth takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to have additional maize profits to send her children to school and secure enough food for her children. In the recent 2011 season, Elizabeth had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 9 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Elizabeth was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Elizabeth will educate her children and save for future use in business and livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Munyofwe Women group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photo above Elizabeth is pictured with her group members and the field officer is standing on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Ashur

texts.ru: Ашур проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 49 лет. Женат. Имеет шестерых детей. Трое его сыновей находятся в России. Сам Ашур занимается скотоводством. В этой области он 10 лет. Кроме того он более 20 лет работает в средней школе, преподавателем. Кредит берет для закупа дойной коровы и теленка.
texts.en: Ashur lives in the Yavan region. He is 49 years old. He is married and has six children. Three of his sons are in Russia. Ashur is in the animal husbandry business. He has been working in this field for ten years. In addition, he has been working in a secondary school as a teacher for more than twenty years. He is taking out the loan to purchase a milk cow and a calf.

loans.use: to buy a milk cow and a calf.

loans.name: Olimjon

texts.ru: Олимджон трудолюбивый молодой человек. Несколько лет он занимается услугами такси. Он женат, отец двоих детей. Он живет недалеко от столицы. Односельчане часто едут в город и он обслуживает их. Услуги таксиста приносят хорошие доходы. К зимнему периоду следует подготовить машину. Он хочет получить займ и отремонтировать машину, купить новые покрышки. Зимой люди чаще ездят на такси. Он надеется на вашу поддержку и благодарен вам.
texts.en: Olimjon is an industrious young man. He has been providing taxi services for several years. He is married and has two children. He lives near the capital. Villagers often go into town and he services them. Taxi driver service brings a good income. The car needs to be in good condition by the winter season. He wants to get a loan and repair the car and buy new tires. In the winter people usually travel by taxi. He looks forward to your support and is thankful.

loans.use: to purchase tires.

loans.name: Imelida

texts.en:
Imelida is a married woman with eight school going children. Her husband is a businessman who contributes to the provision of their family's basic needs. She lives in a rental house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Imelida has operated a tailoring business for the past twenty years; her potential clients are the local area residents. She faces a major challenge of rising prices of materials. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase more stocks of fabrics for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of fabrics for her business.

loans.name: Celine

texts.fr:
Mme CELINE est mariée et mère de 04 enfants. Le plus âgé a 25ans et le moins âgé a 07ans. Les 04 vont à l’école et elle à 06 personnes à sa charge.

Elle fabrique et vend du savon liquide depuis 05ans. Mme s’approvisionne au marché de paglayiri et au grand marché en ville. Ses clients sont les femmes et hommes dans les services,voisins et amis.

Elle veut s’acheter 04kg de soude caustique, 15kg de sel colorant et ¼ de parfum.

Avec  ses bénéfices, elle épargne et prend soin de ses enfants. Elle ambitionne ouvrir une grande boutique et aider à la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Céline is married and a mother of four.  Her oldest child is 25 and her youngest is seven.  All four children attend school and she has six people total in her care.

For five years, she has been making and selling liquid soap.  She gets her supplies at the Paglayiri market and at the large market in town.  Her clients are women and men in the services sector, neighbors and friends.

She would like to purchase 4 kg of caustic soda, 15 kg of dye salts and ¼ of perfume.

She uses her profits to build savings and care for her children.  It is her goal to open a large boutique and help pay for her children’s education.

loans.use: to purchase 4 kg of caustic soda, 15 kg of dye salts and 1/4 of perfume

loans.name: Sitan

texts.fr:
Sitan est une femme mariée de plus 41 ans et mère de quatre enfants , elle vit avec son époux et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso.
 Sitan mène cette activité d’achat et vente de bois de chauffage et poissons fumé il y a dix ans. Elle jouit d’une forte réputation dans cette activité et reçoit beaucoup de commandes surtout en saison froide, mais ses ressources ne peuvent pas lui permettre de les satisfaire. Ainsi, elle a besoin de ce huitième prêt individuel pour acheter 15 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffage dans les localités environnantes de la ville de Sikasso  et 20 cartons de poissons fumés à Gao (7ème région administrative du Mali) afin de satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’accroitre.
   Ses marchandises (respectivement bois de chauffe et poissons fumés) sont vendues au domicile et au marché du quartier.  
   Elle est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus cinq ans dont elle a bénéficié de quatre prêts solidaires avec une association des femmes de son quartier et est maintenant à son huitième prêt individuel, tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
    Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utiliser pour  réaliser l’essentielle de ses dépenses, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Sitan is a married woman, 41 years old and mother of four children. She lives with her husband and children in Sanoubougou I, one of the working-class neighborhoods in the city of Sikasso.

Sitan has worked for ten years buying and selling firewood and smoked fish. She has a good reputation in this business and receives many orders, especially during the cold season, but she does not have sufficient resources to fulfill all her orders. Thus, she needs an eighth individual loan to buy 15 cartloads of firewood in the communities surrounding the city of Sikasso and 20 cases of smoked fish in Gao (the seventh administrative region of Mali) in order to meet the needs of her ever increasing clientele.

Her goods (firewood and smoked fish) are sold from her home and in the local  market.
She has been collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso for more than five years and has benefited from four group loans with a group of the women in her neighborhood, and she is now on her eighth individual loan. All her previous loans have been properly reimbursed.

With this loan, she hopes to make a monthly profit of 150,000 FCFA, which she will use to cover her basic expenses, contribute to the family's expenses and pay the interest on the loan. She will invest the rest in her business.

loans.use: to buy firewood and smoked fish.

loans.name: Vitoria

texts.en:
Vitoria is a 44-year-old woman living in the town of Tufutafoe.  She is married and has eight adult-aged children.  To make a living, Vitoria owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting taro for sale.  Vitoria has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 480 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Vitoria joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Vitoria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1650 WST from SPBD.  This previous loan was used to purchase harvesting equipment.  Vitoria is now requesting a new loan of 1750 WST which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment.  The loan will be the fourth loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Vitoria plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies and equipment.

loans.name: Komera I Group

texts.fr:
Marie Leatitie est une commerçante âgée de 33 ans qui habite la localité de Rutonde de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle vend de la bière locale de bananes et les avocats depuis 10 ans,un métier qu’elle commence alors qu’elle était cultivatrice. Elle a fait ses études jusq’en 6 è année primaire. Elle est mariée à Jean Claude et ont ensemble 5 enfants dont 3 sont à l'école.
Le crédit Kiva de 50,000 francs burundais q’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter une grande quantité de bière locale et des avocats à revendre afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses economies 
Elle est membre du groupe communautaire KOMERA I
