texts.en: Marie Leatitie is a 33-year-old saleswoman living in the town of Rutonde in the Gitega province in the middle of the country.  For 10 years, she has been selling local beer, bananas and avocados, a job that she started when she was working as a farmer.  She completed her education through the sixth year of elementary school.  She is married to Jean Claude; together they have 5 children, 3 of whom attend school.  This Kiva loan of 50,000 B. francs that she is receiving will enable her to increase her capital to buy a large quantity of local beer and avocados for retail sale, in order to make significant profits and increase her savings.  She is a member of the community group Komera 1.

loans.use: to increase her capital to purchase a large quantity of local beer and avocados for retail sale in order to make significant profits and increase her savings

loans.name: Gagik

texts.en:
Gagik, age 50, lives in Ddmashen village in the Sevan area with his mother, wife, son, and daughter. Gagik’s mother is a pensioner and his wife is unemployed. His daughter is a nurse, but at present she is working as a shop assistant. Gagik’s son is a student at the Gavar branch of Yerevan State University. Gagik himself graduated from Yerevan water conservation technical school, and after that he worked at different organizations. Now he is a pensioner. 

Since 2010, Gagik has been engaged in farming. On his farm he has four cows, two calves, and 20 chickens. Part of his agricultural produce (milk, meat, and eggs) he sells to his neighbors. Gagik’s wife helps him a lot and thus they provide for their family and pay for their son’s education. 

This is Gagik’s third loan from Nor Horizon and he has never been delayed in his repayments. Now he is asking for a 1,000,000 AMD loan in order to buy fodder for his farm animals, and he will also purchase a number of sheep, which will allow Gagik to develop his farm and to increase his family’s income.

loans.use: to buy fodder for his farm animals and to buy a number of sheep

loans.name: Luyeshe Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Luyeshe SHG Group in Western Kenya! Benerd is the facilitator of the Luyeshe SHG group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Benerd takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Benerd had a good maize yield, harvesting 12 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Benerd was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Benerd and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Benerd will educate his children, ensure food security, and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Luyeshe SHG group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize. Benerd is pictured with his group members in the photograph.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en:
Carolyne is a married woman with two children, one of whom is enrolled in school while one is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is rent. 

Carolyne has operated a second hand clothes selling business for the past year.  Her potential clients are local area women. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase more second hand clothing for resale. She decided to join Yehu because they offer quality financial services.

loans.use: to purchase more second hand clothing for resale.

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.en: Bernardo is married and has two children. He is a farmer in the Philippines, who is willing to do everything to lift his family out of poverty. He has been working in this field for 30 years and earns PHP 28,000 per crop season. According to him, with the income he has generated from his business he has been able to send his children to school. Right now, Bernardo wants to take out a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy farm supplies such as fertilizers and seedlings. He hopes that he can get the amount he requested to further expand his farm business.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies such as fertilizers and seedlings.

loans.name: Virgen De La Misericordia Group

texts.es:
Virgen de la Misericordia se denomina el excelente grupo de mujeres conformado en la ciudad de Itá, son mujeres muy unidas y trabajadoras. Ellas diariamente luchan por darle a sus hijos y familiares las condiciones mínimas para que tengan una vida digna y decorosa.
La señora Maria trabaja diariamente desde muy tempranas hora y regresa a su casa ya muy entrada la noche. Nos comenta que tiene una peluquería modesta pero bien equipada, allí ella puede generar los ingresos necesarios para ayudar a su familia y darles un mejor futuro.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de peines, tijeras, gel, acondicionadores, shampoo y demás insumos necesarios para su salón.
texts.en:
“Virgen de la Misericordia” is the name of this excellent group of women from the city of Itá; they are very united, hardworking women.  Every day the struggle to provide their children and family members the minimum conditions needed to have a proper, dignified life.

María starts work very early and returns home quite late at night.  She comments that she has a modest, but well-equipped, beauty salon where she’s able to earn the necessary income to help her family and give them a better future.

She requests the loan to buy combs, scissors, gel, conditioner, shampoo and other supplies needed in her beauty salon.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Birashoboka 1 Group

texts.fr:
Joselyne est une commerçante âgé de 32 ans qui habite la localité de  Gasenyi en Mairie de Bujumbura . Elle est vendeuse  de divers produits commes des limonades, du lait et le télephone public depuis 10 ans, un métier qu’elle commence alors qu’elle était boutiquière. Elle a fait ses études jusq’en 6è année primaire. Elle est mariée à Alphonse qui est un maçon et ont ensemble 3 enfants qui étudient.
Le crédit Kiva de 250,000 francs burundais q’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter une grande quantité de caisse de fanta ainsi qu’une grande quantité de lait à revendre afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses economies 
Elle est membre du groupe communautaire BIRASHOBOKA 1
texts.en:
Joselyne is a 32-year-old saleswoman living in the town of Gasenyi in the Bujumbura Mairie province.  For 10 years, she has worked selling various items like soft drinks and milk and running a public telephone - a career path she started on when she was working in a boutique.  She completed her education through the 6th year of elementary school.  She is married to Alphonse, a builder, and together they have 3 children who all attend school.  This Kiva loan of 250,000 Burundi francs that she is receiving will enable her increase her capital to purchase a large quantity of cases of Fanta, as well as a large quantity of milk for retail sale in order to make significant profits and increase her savings.

She is a member of the community group Birashoboka 1.

loans.use: to increase her capital for purchasing a large quantity of boxes of Fanta, and of milk for retail sale, in order to make significant profits and increase her savings

loans.name: Birashoboka 2 Group

texts.fr:
Anne  Marie est une commerçante âgé de 44 ans qui habite la localité de  Gihosha en Mairie de Bujumbura . Elle est vendeuse  de bière locale depuis 30 ans. Elle n’a pas fréquenté l’école . Elle est mariée à Prosper et ont ensemble 5 enfants qui étudient .Sa famille prend en charge 3 orphelins de parenté proche qui étudient.
Le crédit Kiva de 320,000 francs burundais q’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter une grande quantité de bière locale à revendre afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses economies 
Elle est membre du groupe communautaire BIRASHOBOKA 2
texts.en:
Anne Marie is a 44-year-old trader who lives in the town of Gihosha en Mairie de Bujumbura. She has been a local beer seller for 30 years. She did not attend school. She is married to Prosper, and they have 5 children together who are in school. Her family has taken 3 orphans of close relatives into their care who are in school.

The Kiva loan of 320,000 burundi francs that she obtains will allow her to increase her capital in order to buy a large quantity of local beer to resell in order to make a large profit and to increase her savings.

She is a member of the community group BIRASHOBOKA 2.

loans.use: to increase her capital in order to buy a large quantity of local beer to resell in order to make a large profit and to increase her savings.

loans.name: Zilper

texts.en:
Zilper is a single mother of one school-going child. She lives in a rental house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees for her child. 

Zilper has operated a café for the past year. Her potential clients are the local area residents. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. She dreams of establishing a hotel in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase a refrigerator for her café. She decided to join Yehu because they offer quality financial services to their clients.

loans.use: to purchase a refrigerator for her café.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 32-year-old, young man who is married with one daughter. He is a taxi driver with a low income. Ahmad wants to repair his taxi by changing its doors but he does not have enough money.Therefore he needs a loan from FATEN. When Ahmad gets the loan, he will replace the taxi doors and this will improve the condition of his taxi. Ahmad will work extra hours to increase his income and provide his family with better living conditions. Ahmad is photographed next to his taxi.

About this loan product:
 FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the cultural context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit Kiva's Muslim World Lending helptext: http://tinyurl.com/3aekx8m.

loans.use: To replace the doors on his taxi.

loans.name: Najma

texts.en:
Najma is applying for another loan to expand her existing business. She will use this 80,000 KES loan to purchase more clothes, window curtains, handbags, and bed sheets for resale. In the future, Najma aspires to continue expanding her business. 

Since taking her last Kiva loan, Najma has greatly improved her family’s standard of living. She hopes to continue accessing the financial services offered by Yehu and Kiva lenders and thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, window curtains, handbags, and bed sheets for resale.

loans.name: Kona Moja Group

texts.en:
Elias is the facilitator of the Kona Moja group. Elias  and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Elias  takes care of seven children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Elias  had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 10 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Elias was only able to harvest 4½ bags of maize on ½ an acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Elias  and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Elias will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Kona Moja  group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Elias is pictured with his group members and standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Jimsher

texts.en:
Jimsher is 46 years old. He lives in the village of Martkopi, East Georgia. He is married and lives with his wife Nino and his father. Jimsher works as an electrical equipment fitter. At the same time, he is actively involved in family agriculture. The family has three milk cows and produces yogurt. They sell, on average, 60 liters of yogurt in Tbilisi (the capital city of the country). The total average monthly income of the family is 400 Laris, including the monthly pension of Jimsher’s father. 

Jimsher takes the finished products to Tbilisi by public transport three times a week, which is quite uncomfortable and costly. He requested credit for purchasing an old car, which will be used for the transportation of dairy products. Jimsher will load the car once a week and take all the products to Tbilisi. It will save on transportation costs, as well as Jimsher’s time. 

In the future, the family plans to purchase more cows in order to expand the dairy farm and increase the income of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a car for the transportation of dairy products.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua sells secondhand clothes at Watreso near Abura. She has been selling secondhand clothing for eight years. Akua is married to a driver and has six dependants. She uses her income to assist her husband in providing for their family. She will use her loan to purchase more clothes for resale. With the new profit, Akua plans to acquire a shop to sell her clothes.

loans.use: purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Tuzamurane Group

texts.fr:
Joseph est un commerçant âgé de 52 ans qui habite la localité de Gitongo de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Il est boutiquier et vend divers articles comme haricot, riz, savons, huile, sel, sucre, etc depuis 30 ans, un métier qu’il commence alors qu’il était cultivateur. Il a fait ses études jusqu’en 5 è année primaire. Il est marié à Baranyuzuriye et ont ensemble 10enfants dont 2 sont à l’école secondaire et 3 au primaire.
Le crédit Kiva de 200,000 francs burundais qu’il obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter une grande quantité d’articles de boutique à revendre afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses économies 
Il est membre du groupe communautaire TUZAMURANE
texts.en:
Joseph is a 52-year-old businessman who lives in the town of Gitongo in the Province of Gitega in the center of the country. He is a shop owner and sells different items such as beans, rice, soap, oil, salt, sugar, etc. For the past 30 years, he has been in the trade which began when he was a farmer. He was in school until the 5th year of elementary school. He is married to Baranyuzuriye and they have 10 children together with 2 in middle school and 3 in elementary school.

The Kiva loan of 200,000 burundi francs that he receives will allow him to increase his capital in order to buy a large quantity of shop items to resell in order to realize large profits and to increase his savings.

He is a member of the TUZAMURANE community group.

loans.use: to increase his capital in order to buy a large quantity of shop items to resell in order to realize large profits and to increase his savings.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is married to a driver and has three children. She sells dresses and clothes in Watreso near Abura. Sarah has been in this business for the past five years. She supports her husband in paying their utility bills. Sarah will use her loan to purchase more dresses and clothes for resale. She wants to use her new profit to get a shop for the sale of her clothes.

loans.use: to purchase more dresses and clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama sells palm oil and palm fruit at Watreso near Abura.  She has been doing this for 30 years.  Her husband is a farmer and they have seven dependents. 
 
Ama uses her income to assist her husband to provide for their family. She will use her loan to purchase more palm fruit for the preparation of the oil.  With the new profit, Ama plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more palm fruit for the preparation of palm oil.

loans.name: Changamka Group

texts.en:
Douglas is the facilitator of the Changamka group. Douglas and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Douglas takes care of seven children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Douglas had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 9 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Douglas was only able to harvest 1 bag of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Douglas and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Douglas will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Changamka group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia is a seamstress in Watreso near Abura. She has been into sewing for 3 years now. She is married to a farmer and has 3 children.  Afia assists her husband to pay utility bills.

She will use her loan to purchase materials for sewing. Afia will use her new profits to get a shop for her sewing.

loans.use: to purchase materials for sewing

loans.name: Bineta Mbengue

texts.fr: Madame Bineta habite au Sénégal et est âgée de 49 ans. Elle est mère de 7 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 10 et 20 ans. Elle évolue dans le secteur de la restauration.  Elle pratique la vente de petit déjeuner et déjeuner, et capitalise une expérience de plus de 15 ans dans son activité qu’elle a choisi par passion. Mais elle est surtout intéressée par les revenus qui lui sont procurés. Elle est sociétaire de l’un des guichets de l’U-IMCEC depuis aout 2011. Elle sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs prévu pour  l’achat de denrées alimentaires qui entre dans la préparation des repas qu’elle vend  tels que riz, huile, haricots, etc... Son objectif est d’acheter en quantité assez importante pour bénéficier  de prix plus compétitifs mais aussi pour gagner du temps et ne pas avoir a se déplacer chaque jour pour acheter ce dont elle a besoin. Elle souhaite ainsi accroitre la rentabilité de son activité car ses bénéfices lui  permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Madame Bineta lives in Senegal and is 49 years old. She has seven children from 10 to 20 years old. She works in catering, offering breakfasts and lunches. She has more than 15 years experience in this business, which she chose because she has a  passion for it. However, she is particularly interested in the income it generates. 

Madame Bineta has been a member of one of the UIMCEC branches since August 2011. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 frs to buy basic ingredients, such as rice, oil, and beans, for the meals that she sells. Her goal is to make her purchases in large enough quantities to benefit from more competitive prices, but also to save time and not have to go out every day to buy what she needs. Thus she hopes to increase the profitability of her business, as the profits would allow her to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for the meals she prepares.

loans.name: Amkatwende Group

texts.en:
Moses takes care of 10 children at home. He joined One Acre Fund because of One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Moses had an excellent maize yield harvesting 11 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Moses was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on ½ an acre of land. With income from maize sales, Moses will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

Moses is the facilitator of the Amkatwende group. In the photograph above, Moses is pictured with his group members. The person standing on the far left is the field officer. Moses and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Amkatwende group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Moses and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Alchynbay

texts.ru: Алчынбай  - 46 летний фермер. Основная деятельность Алчынбая – животноводство и полеводство.  В 2003 году, в поисках источника дохода для своей  семьи, Алчынбай  организовал  собственное хозяйство и начал заниматься разведением скота и полеводством, стартовав с суммой в 18,000 сом (KGS). На сегодняшний день, хозяйство Алчынбая приносит около 12,000 сом (KGS) ежемесячно.  Для дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Алчынбай обратился в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 80,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дополнительной скотины. В будущем, Алчынбай планирует расширять поголовье скота.
texts.en: Alchynbay is a 46 year old farmer. The main activity of Alchynbay is livestock and arable farming. In 2003 in search of a source of income for his family Alchynbay organized his own farm having started with the sum of 18,000 soms (KGS) and began raising livestock and arable farming. Today his farm brings about 12,000 som (KGS) per month. For further development of his business Alchynbay has come to Bai Tushum & Partners for a loan in the amount of 80,000 KGS to buy more cattle. In the future Alchynbay plans to expand the headcount of cattle.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Felista's Group

texts.en:
Felista's Group is comprised of 3 hardworking women. Felista is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children who are all currently in school. For the past 2 years, Felista has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Felista has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for resale, and will help Felista to generate greater profits and buy food to feed her family. Felista hopes that, in the future, she will be able to learn a job skill in hairdressing. 

Felista is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Felista's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Muchanja Farmers Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Muchanja Farmers Group in Western Kenya! Njomo is the facilitator of the group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Njomo joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Njomo had a very good maize yield, harvesting 10 bags on 1/2 an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Njomo was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on 1/2 an acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Njomo and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Njomo will educate his children, ensure food security, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Muchanja Farmers group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Sa

texts.en:
Sa is a 32-year-old woman living in the town of Satupaitea Vaega.  She is married and has 2 infant children.  To make a living, Sa owns and operates a business making and selling cooked food to local communities.  Sa has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1,200 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Sa joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Sa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,000 WST from SPBD.  This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business.

Sa is now requesting a new loan of 1,000 WST which will be used to purchase an oven, mutton flaps (mutton or lamb belly meat), sausages, plastic plates and tissues.  This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Sa from SPBD.

Sa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: to purchase an oven, mutton flaps, sausages, plastic plates and tissues

loans.name: Caroline's Group

texts.en:
Caroline's Group is comprised of 2 hardworking women. Caroline is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, Caroline has been working hard to manage her poultry farm, which sells chicken. 

To help expand her business, Caroline has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more chicken for resale, and will help Caroline to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself. Caroline hopes that in the future she will be able to study catering. 

Caroline is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Caroline's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more chicken for resale

loans.name: Wesakulila Group

texts.en:
Andrew is the facilitator of the Wesakulila group. Andrew and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Andrew takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Andrew had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 10 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Andrew was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Andrew and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Andrew will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Wesakulila group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Juliet's Group

texts.en:
Juliet's Group is comprised of 2 hardworking women. Juliet is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Juliet has been working hard to manage her hotel (restaurant), which sells food. 

To help expand her business, Juliet has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy food to cook for resale, and will help Juliet to generate greater profits and open up another shop that does hairdressing. Juliet hopes that in the future she will be able to own a salon business. 

Juliet is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Juliet's future prospects by helping her improve her business.

loans.use: to buy food to cook for resale

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Group

texts.es:
El comité “Mujeres Unidas” es de la ciudad de Asunción, se encuentran en el quinto ciclo del programa de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya, todas las integrantes ya realizan actividades individuales y también grupal con las cuales pueden fomentar la union del grupo.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Maria, quien se dedica a la venta de calzados deportivos de todo tipo. Comenta que gracias a la calidad de sus productos y a la amabilidad con que atiende a sus clientes, ella ha logrado salir adelante y ayudar a su familia. Ella desea seguir creciendo y es por ello que solicita la ayuda de la fundacion y de kiva.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de calzados deportivos de todo tipo.
texts.en:
Mujeres Unidas Communal Bank is in the city of Asunción.  They are in the fifth cycle of the Mujeres Emprendedoras program of Fundación Paraguaya.  All of the members are already working in individual activities as well as group activities in which they can encourage group unity.

One of the members is María, who works selling athletic shoes of all types.  She comments that, thanks to the quality of her products and the kindness with which she serves her customers, she has managed to get ahead and help her family.  She wants to continue growing and this is why she is requesting the help of the foundation and Kiva.

She is requesting the loan to buy athletic shoes of all types.

loans.use: to buy athletic shoes to sell.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a 58-year-old farmer from the village Kumisi, East Georgia. He is married and lives with his family: wife Evgenia, 2 sons (28 and 22 years old), daughter-in-law and 2 grandchildren.

The main source of the income for the family is agriculture. They own 4 milk cows and 8 calves. The family sells milk, yogurt and cheese in Tbilisi (the capital city of Georgia). The family also sells besom which they make. the total average monthly family income is 1000 Laris.

David requested credit to build a house roof. The family has constructed a new house which needs a roof. When it is finished, David’s elder son (married) will move into it with his family. They will have more space and better living conditions for the children and the whole family.

loans.use: to build a roof

loans.name: Twishingane Group

texts.fr:
Gaudence est une commerçante âgée de 44 ans qui habite la localité de Nyabitanga de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle vend la farine de manioc depuis 14 ans,un métier qu’elle commence alors qu’elle était cultivatrice. Elle a fait ses études jusq’en 6 è année primaire. Elle est mariée à Bernard et ont ensemble 7 enfants dont 6 sont à l’ecole.
Le crédit Kiva qu’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter une grande quantité de farine de manioc à revendre afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses economies 
Elle est membre du groupe communautaire TWISHINGANE
texts.en: Gaudence is a 44-year-old entrepreneur who lives in Nyabitanga, in the Gitega province of central Burundi.  She has been selling cassava flour for 14 years.  She started this professional activity when she was a farmer.  She is educated through the sixth year of primary school.  She is married to Bernard, and they have 7 children together, 6 of whom attend school.  The credit requested from Kiva, (50,000 Burundian Francs), helps her increase her capital in order to buy large quantities of cassava flour that will be resold at a profit in order to increase cash-flow.  She is a member of the Twishingane community group.

loans.use: To increase her capital in order to buy large quantities of cassava flour to be resold at a profit, in order to increase cash-flow

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua is a single parent and has 2 children. She sells banku (a corn dough) and stew at Watreso near Abura. She has been in this business for the past 5 years now.  Akua is responsible for the upkeep of her children.

She will use her loan to purchase bulk maize for the preparation of the banku. Ekua plans to expand her business with the new profits.

loans.use: to purchase bulk maize for the preparation of banku

loans.name: Agnes' Group

texts.en:
Agnes' Group is comprised of 2 hardworking women. Agnes is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Agnes has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells bread. 

To help expand her business, Agnes has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more bread for resale, and will help Agnes to generate greater profits and buy new clothes for herself. Agnes hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house of her own. 

Agnes is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Agnes's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more bread for resale

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa is married to a farmer and has 6 dependents. She sells vegetables at Watreso near Abura. She has been selling vegetables for 3 years.  She uses her income to assist her husband to provide for their family.

She will use her loan to buy more vegetables for sale. With the new profits, Yaa will expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables for sale

loans.name: Sumaya

texts.en:
Sumaya is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children, with 1 of them currently in school. For the past 3 years, Sumaya has been working hard to manage her small farm, which does poultry keeping. 

To help expand her business, Sumaya has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more chickens for resale, and will help Sumaya to generate greater profits and pay for medical expenses. Sumaya hopes that in the future she will be able to own a retail shop. 

Sumaya is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Sumaya's future prospects by helping her with money that has increased the capital of her business.

loans.use: to buy more chickens for resale

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Madame Awa est une femme mariée qui  vit au Sénégal. Elle est âgée  de 35 ans et  est mère de 4 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 1 et 9 ans.  Elle exerce une activité diversifiée de commerce de vente d’habits  et de  repas (petit déjeuner et déjeuner). Elle capitalise une expérience de 5 ans dans son activité.  Elle a choisi cette activité de commerce par amour,  pour gagner des revenus qui lui permettent de satisfaire ses besoins. Elle est membre d’un des guichets de l’U-IMCEC depuis juillet 2006. Elle sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs prévu pour l’achat de tissus et de quelques denrées qui vont aider a la préparation des repas qu’elle commercialise. Son but recherché est l’accroissement d e ses bénéfices et l’amélioration  des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Madame Awa is a married woman who lives in Senegal. She is 35 years old and has four children aged between one and nine. She has diversified business activities, selling clothing and meals (breakfast and lunch). She has worked in this business for five years. She chose this line of work because she loves it, and also to generate an income that allows her to cover her needs.
 
Madame Awa has been a member of one of the branches of the UIMCEC since July 2006. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 frs to buy fabrics and a few commodities for preparing the meals she sells. Her aim is the increase her profits and the improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fabrics to sell and ingredients for preparing the meals she sells.

loans.name: Bintihamisi

texts.en:
Bintihamisi is applying for another loan to expand her existing business. She will use this 80,000 KES loan to purchase spare parts to repair her motorcycle and also buy a new motorcycle. In the future, Bintihamisi aspires to continue improving her business. 

Since taking her last Kiva loan, Bintihamisi has greatly improved her family’s standard of living. She hopes to continue accessing the financial services offered by Yehu and Kiva lenders and thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase spare parts to repair her motorcycle and also buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua is a fishmonger at Watreso near Abura. She has done this for one year now. 

Ekua is married to a farmer and has two children. She uses her income to assist her husband in paying utility bills. 

She will use her loan to buy more fish. With her new profit, she will expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish.

loans.name: Sarah Adwoa

texts.en: Sarah Adwoa is married to a palm wine tapper and has two children. She sells secondhand footwear. She has been in this business for the past three years. Sarah uses her income to support her husband in paying their children’s school fees. She will use her loan to purchase more secondhand footwear. With her new profit, Sarah wants to get a shop to sell her goods.

loans.use: purchase more secondhand footwear.

loans.name: Bihija

texts.en:
Bihija is a single lady who lives at her family’s house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Bihija has operated a beauty salon for the past two years; her potential clients are the local area ladies. She faces a major challenge of insecurity. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase a blow dry machine and repair her drier. She decided to join Yehu because of their fair terms and conditions.

loans.use: To purchase a blow dry machine and repair her drier.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children who are all currently in school. For the past 1 year, Rose has been working hard to manage her hotel, which sells food. 

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy food for cooking for resale, and will help Rose to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Rose hopes that in the future she will be able to own a taxi vehicle. 

Rose is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Rose's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy food to cook for resale

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce sells fried eggs and sweet potatoes at Watreso. She is married with 5 dependants. She has done this for 5 years now. Joyce uses her income to assists her husband to provide for their family. 

Joyce will use her loan to buy eggs and sweet potatoes in bulk for resale. With the new profits, Joyce plans to expand her business.

loans.use: buy eggs and sweet potatoes in bulk for resale

loans.name: Njiyobiri Group

texts.fr:
Triphonie est une commerçante âgée de 41 ans qui habite la localité de Nyabitanga de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle vend les bananes depuis 25 ans,un métier qu’elle commence alors qu’elle était cultivatrice. Elle a fait ses études jusq’en 6 è année primaire. Elle est mariée à Louis et ont ensemble 8 enfants dont 2 sont à l’école primaire et 3 à l'école secondaire.
Le crédit Kiva de 150,000 francs burundais q’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter une grande quantité de bananes à revendre afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses economies 
Elle est membre du groupe communautaire NJIYOBIRI
texts.en:
Triphonie is 41-year-old saleswoman living in the town of Nyabitanga in the Gitega province in the middle of the country.  For 25 years, she has been working selling bananas, a job she began when she was working as a farmer.  She completed her education through the sixth year of elementary school.  She is married to Louis, and together they have eight children, two of which are in elementary school and 3 of which are in secondary school.

The Kiva loan of 150,000 Burundi francs that she is receiving will enable her to increase her capital to purchase a large quantity of bananas for retail sale in order to make significant profits and increase her savings.

She is a member of the Njiyobiri community group.

loans.use: to increase her capital to purchase a large quantity of bananas for retail sale in order to make significant profits and increase her savings

loans.name: Yudaya's Group

texts.en:
Yudaya's group is comprised of 2 hard working women. Yudaya is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. For the past 1 year, Yudaya has been working hard to manage her salon, which does hairdressing for local women. 

To help expand her business, Yudaya has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase the equipment needed to do special braids, and will help Yudaya to generate greater profits and pay for her mother’s medical bills. Yudaya hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house of her own. 

Yudaya is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Yudaya's future prospects by teaching her how to be hard working.

loans.use: to purchase the equipment needed to do special braids

loans.name: Kwambane Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Kwambane Group in Western Kenya! Jemimah is the facilitator of Kwambane group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Jemimah is a mother of four children. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to feed her family and access fertilizer and hybrid seeds to ensure quality harvest from her farm. In the recent 2011 season, Jemimah had a good maize yield, harvesting 7 bags on 1/2 an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jemimah was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on 1/2 an acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jemimah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Jemimah will educate her children, ensure food security, and invest in livestock rearing.

 In 2012, the members of Kwambane group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize. Jemimah is pictured in the photograph with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Lovinsa's Group

texts.en:
Lovinsa's group is comprised of 2 hard working women. Lovinsa is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, with 1 of them currently in school. For the past 2 years, Lovinsa has been working hard to manage her small market, which sells food. 

To help expand her business, Lovinsa has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food for resale, and will help Lovinsa to generate greater profits and buy food to feed her family. Lovinsa hopes that in the future she will be able to own a plot of land. 

Lovinsa is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Lovinsa's future prospects by helping her improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more food for resale

loans.name: Chebin A W Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Chebin A W Group in Western Kenya! With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Irene and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Irene takes care of two children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Irene had a very good maize yield harvesting 20 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Irene was only able to harvest 10 bags of maize on 1 acre of land. With income from maize sales, Irene will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

Irene is the facilitator of the Chebin A W group. The photograph shows Irene with her group members. Standing on the far left is the field officer. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Chebin A W group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua  is a fish monger at Watreso. She is married to a farmer with seven dependents.  She has been a fish monger for the past seven years now. Ahosua assists her husband in the up keep of their children. She will use her loan to purchase more fish. Akosua will expand her business with her new profit.

loans.use: purchase more fish.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. She is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past 2 years, Florence has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sugar and soap for resale, and it will help Florence to generate greater profits and buy food to feed her family. Florence hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Florence is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Florence’s future prospects by helping her improve her business.

loans.use: to buy sugar and soap for resale.

loans.name: Lazia's Group

texts.en:
Lazia's group is comprised of three hard working women. Lazia is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past two years, Lazia has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells shoes. 

To help expand her business, Lazia has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more shoes for resale, and will help Lazia generate greater profits and pay school fees for her child. Lazia hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Lazia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Lazia's future prospects by teaching her how to save.

loans.use: to buy more shoes for resale.

loans.name: Shalon's Group

texts.en:
Shalon's group is comprised of two hard working women. Shalon is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. For the past year, Shalon has been working hard to manage her small market, which sells food. 

To help expand her business, Shalon has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy food for resale, and will help Shalon generate greater profits and buy books to help her through her studies. Shalon hopes that in the future she will be able to study nursing. 

Shalon is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Shalon's future prospects by helping her improve her business.

loans.use: to buy food for resale.

loans.name: 11 De Septiembre Group

texts.es:
El grupo 11 de Septiembre es de la ciudad de Asunción, esta integrado por 20 mujeres, todas ellas amigas y vecinas de esa ciudad, Actualmente se encuentran en el segundo ciclo del programa de mujeres emprendedoras de la fundación paraguaya. Ellas se unieron con el propósito de darle a sus familias e hijos una vida son privaciones ni limitaciones.
Gregoria es una de las miembros, ella comenta que trabaja arduamente, pues sabe que trabajando es la única forma en la que se puede sobresalir y ayudar a la familia. Ella es modista y cuenta que se dedica a esto hace ya un buen tiempo, por lo que ya tiene muy buena clientela. Ella tiene el sueño de convertirse en una gran modista, y lo quiere lograr a través de su trabajo.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de telas, hilos, botones, cierres y demás insumos necesaR. para su taller. Agradece a la fundación y a kiva por la oportunidad que estas le dan de acceder a una ayuda.
texts.en:
The 11 de Septiembre group is located in the city of Asunción. It is made up of 20 women, all friends and neighbours from Asuncion. They are currently in the second cycle of the Female Entrepreneurs' Program in Fundación Paraguaya. They joined together with the goal of giving their families a life without hardship or limitations.
Gregoria is one of the members. She says that she works very hard, since she knows that working is the only way to succeed and help her family. She is modest and tells us that she has been working for some time now, so she has a very good customer base. Her dream is to become a largescale designer, and she hopes to achieve this through her work.
She is requesting this loan for the purchase of fabric, thread, buttons, clasps, and other items for her workshop. She thanks the Fundacion and Kiva for the opportunity that they are providing her to access help.

loans.use: to buy fabric, buttons, clasps, and more tools.

loans.name: Afia

texts.en: Afia is married to a palm wine tapper and has three children. Afia sells maize porridge at Watreso. She has been doing this for three years now. Afia uses her income to support her husband to pay utility bills. She will use her loan to purchase bulk maize for her porridge. Afia will expand her business with her new profit.

loans.use: purchase bulk maize for her porridge.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a single lady who lives in a rental house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is house rent. 

Asha has operated a beauty salon for the past two years. Her potential clients are the local area ladies. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase hair relaxers, hair extensions and cosmetics for her salon. She decided to join Yehu to access fund to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase hair relaxers, hair extensions and cosmetics for her salon.

loans.name: Mitoto Women Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Mitoto Women Group in Western Kenya! 

Mary takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Mary had an excellent maize yield harvesting 8 bags on 1/2 an acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Mary was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on 1/2 an acre of land. With income from maize sales, Mary will educate her children.

Mary is the facilitator of the Mitoto Women group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Mitoto Women group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Mary and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Zubeda

texts.en:
Zubeda is a married woman with three children, two of whom are enrolled in school, while the other one is too young for school. Her husband, who is employed, also contributes to the provision of family basic needs. She owns a house with piped water but no electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Zubeda has operated a nursery school for the past four years; her potential clients are the local area children. She faces a major challenge of competition from other education providers. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase more chairs, desks and school uniforms. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more chairs, desks and school uniforms.

loans.name: Soita W Group

texts.en:
Rose joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Rose had an excellent maize yield harvesting 14 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Rose was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on one acre of land. With income from maize sales, Rose will invest in livestock rearing and; hence, educate her children.

Rose is the facilitator of the Soita W group. The photograph shows Rose with her group members. The field officer is on the far left. Rose and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Soita W group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Rose and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Vazha

texts.en: Vazha is from the village Vashlovani, East Georgia. He is 50 years old and lives with his family: his wife, Makvala, and 22-year-old son. All the family members are involved in agriculture. They have 2 milk cows and produce cheese which is sold in Tbilisi (the capital city of the country). Along with the dairy farm, Vazha trades calves. He purchases calves, raises them and then sells them at a higher price. The total average monthly income of the family is 800 Laris. Vazha requested credit to purchase additional calves. He will sell them in spring. It will bring additional income to the family which will be used to further expand the family’s dairy farm.

loans.use: to purchase calves for resale

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma's group is comprised of hard working women. Mwajuma is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past 2 years, Mwajuma has been working hard to manage her small market, which sells food. 

To help expand her business, Mwajuma has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food for resale, which will help Mwajuma generate greater profits and pay for her mother’s medication. Mwajuma hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Mwajuma is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Mwajuma's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more food for resale.

loans.name: Sinoko Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Sinoko Group in Western Kenya! 

Mary takes care of three children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Mary had a very good maize yield harvesting 12 bags on 1/2 an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Mary was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on 1/2 an acre of land. With income from maize sales, Mary will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing. 

Mary is the facilitator of the Sinoko group. She is pictured with her group members in the photograph. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Sinoko group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Mary and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Nyakagezi Gamba Nokora Group

texts.en:
Bushenyi like many other districts in the West of Uganda is predominately a farming area. Most of Bushenyi's indigenous people are engaged in agriculture as a source of livelihood.
Farming for both commercial and subsistence purposes, is a handed down practice in Bushenyi and one will be hard pressed not to find a family that is not bearing a hand in the aforementioned.
On occasion, some seasons play havoc with farmer’s harvests. Other adverse seasons spell stagnation in terms of planting as there is barely rainfall. This however has not made any of Bushenyi's farmers waver in their determination to be the preeminent food providing district in Uganda.
Anybody who has been to the many food markets in the nation's capital-Kampala can bear witness to the fact that most food being sold is from Bushenyi.
How would one know and tell? Well the language being spoken by the food traders on their big trucks is alien in Kampala.That would be one way of identifying these traders.
The Bushenyi farmers too have a different type of bananas, a high favored staple food in Kampala, which they sell in these flourishing markets. Their bananas are really big. As in really BIG. And these sell quite highly in Kampala.
One farmer from Bushenyi who has for the last decade been involved in this trade is 49 year old Abasi, a happily married father of eight children.
He has been doing great business in this trade and it explains his relative longevity.
He sells his foods not only in Kampala, but in most towns of Western Uganda.
He says that a sense of unwavering hard work and determination has enabled him to carve out a significant niche for his business.
Month in, month out, he says his sales returns are to the tune of 150,000 Ugandan shillings.
Abasi intends to use his Kiva loan to purchase high grade manure for his farms.

loans.use: to purchase high grade manure for his farm.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is 59 years old, married, and a father of three children. He owns and has been running a green grocery business in Mombasa for the last 10 years, and with this business he receives an income of KES 10, 000 in a month.

He has applied for his second loan from KADET LTD, after paying back the previous loans well and in good time. He plans to use the loan to purchase more stock of vegetables, onions and tomatoes in order to satisfy his customers.

He will save the anticipated profits and pay back the loan. He hopes to grow his business and open a retail shop in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of vegetables, onions and tomatoes.

loans.name: Izabella

texts.en:
Izabella is a married woman with two children one of whom attends schools while the other one is too young for school. Her husband is a seaman who contributes to the provision of family basic needs. She lives in a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Izabella has operated a beauty salon for the past three years; her potential clients are the local area ladies. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase more stocks of hair relaxers, hair extensions and cosmetics for her salon. She decided to join Yehu because they offer quality financial services.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of hair relaxers, hair extensions and cosmetics for her salon.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Group

texts.es:
El comité Mujeres Unidas nace mediante la gestión y el apoyo D. otro comité que se encontraba trabajando en dicho lugar. Mujeres Unidas es D. la Ciudad D. San Lorenzo, las integrantes fijaron como objetivo principal el crecimiento D. cada una D. ellas en lo personal como también en lo laboral, ya que desean ayudar a sus familias por medio D. ese trabajo.
La Sra. Ignacia es la presidenta del grupo, es una mujer muy emprendedora y muy capaz, ya que ella lidera un grupo numeroso como lo es este, durante todos estos ciclos ha demostrado ganas D. superación. Ella comenta que se dedica a la venta D. todo tipo D. productos, como ser sabanas, prendas, colchas, frazadas y demás, con las cuales ha podido sacar adelante a su familia y paliar los gastos diarios.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra D. sabanas, frazadas y demás productos con los cuales pueD. abastecerse y seguir con sus ventas.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Unidas ["United Women"] group was born thanks to the negotiations and support of the other committee that was working in the area. The group is located in the city of San Lorenzo. The members' main goal is for each of them to grow personally and professionally, since they want to help their families through this work.
Mrs. Ignacia is the group president. She is a very enterprising and capable woman, as she is leading such a large group. Throughout their loan cycles, she has demonstrated a desire to succeed. She tells us that she sells all sorts of items, such as sheets, clothing, bedspreads, blankets, and more. With these sales, she has been able to get her family ahead and cover their daily costs.
She is requesting a loan for the purchase of sheets, blankets, and other products so that she can stock up and keep selling.

loans.use: to buy sheets, blankets, and other products for the next sale.

loans.name: Sandra Milena

texts.es: La señora Sandra, a sus 29 años de edad, se dedica desde su propio negocio a la elaboración y venta de comida como empanadas, papas y otros alimentos como gaseosa y snakcs. El sector donde tiene localizado su  negocio es al lado de una quebrada. La señora Sandra tiene 29 años de edad y es madre de dos hijos, uno de ello de seis años y el otro de 16 meses de edad. Actualmente, la señora Sandra desea comprar una nevera y surtido de snakcs para su negocio con el fin de poder aumentar sus ingresos y brindar una mejor calidad de vida a sus dos hijos. El sueño de la señora Sandra es tener su propio local de comidas rápidas.
texts.en: Mrs. Sandra, at the age of 29, has her own business making and selling food such as empanadas, potatoes, and other foods such as pop and snacks. Her business is located next to a stream. Sandy has two children ages 6 and 16 months. She now wants to buy a fridge and snacks for her business. Her goal is to increase her income and offer her children a better quality of life. Sandra's dream is to have her own fast food restaurant.

loans.use: to buy a fridge.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary, a mother of five school-going children, is married to a driver who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. She owns a house with electricity and piped water, and her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children.

Mary has operated a fabric-selling business for the past ten years; her potential clients are the local area ladies. She faces a major challenge of transportation, and dreams of establishing a shop to sell her products from.

Having decided to join Yehu to access funds to expand her business, Mary is requesting a loan of Kshs 70,000 to purchase more stocks of fabrics for resale.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of fabrics for resale.

loans.name: Tabita

texts.en: Tabita, a 33-year-old mother of two children aged four and seven, both in school, is married to an agronomist. Tabita sells a variety of products such as rice, sugar, and salt in a store that she has run for three years. She would like a loan to increase her inventory of goods to sell in her store. Any profits from the business will be used to provide food for her family and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Sozar

texts.en:
Sozar is a farmer from the village Aghaiani, East Georgia. He is 36 years old, married and lives with his big family: his wife, Ledi, his two daughters (12 and 5 years old), his 3-year-old son and his retired parents. Sozar’s elder daughter goes to school. Ledi is a housewife. Sozar and his parents are involved in the family agricultural business. They have 3 milk cows and sell home made cheese in grocery stores in Tbilisi (the capital city of the country). Sozar also runs a bakery where he sells bread. The total average income of the family is 500 Laris per month. 

Sozar requested credit to expand his agricultural business. He plans to purchase three calves and grow them during the winter months. In spring Sozar will sell the calves at a higher price and make a profit. The family will use the additional profit to improve the living conditions of their children and the other family members.

loans.use: to purchase calves

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy shoes, cosmetics, general clothing, and perfume, among other items.

loans.name: Delfina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “PEROLNIYOC DE URUBAMBA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Urubamba, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Delfina; ella tiene 30 años de edad y es soltera; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de agricultura, ella siembra maíz, la socia también se dedica a trabajar como docente secundaria en el distrito de Urubamba, por medio de este negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio de agricultura. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar maíz al por mayor y fertilizantes para las tierras de cultivo. 

 La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the “PEROLNIYOC DE URUBAMBA” communal bank. The bank is located in the Urubamba district, belonging to the province of Urubamba and the department of Cusco. 
This is Mrs. Delfina. She is 30 and single. She alternates her daily chores with agriculture. She sows corn. She also works as a secondary school teacher in the Urubamba district. She is getting her children ahead through her business. She wants to expand and improve her agriculture business. She is requesting this loan to buy corn wholesale, as well as fertilizers for her farmland.

She is happy to have this loan and promises to repay her quotas on time.

loans.use: to buy corn wholesale, and fertilizers for her farmland.

loans.name: Americo

texts.en: El socio Americo; El socio es jubilado y se dedica  a los arreglos en el hogar, el apoya a su conyugue a pagar el envio de la ropa que su hija les envia desde la ciudad de Lima, para que su mamá venda en Cusco, , el socio tambien en esta ocasión apoyara a comprar, caramelos, chocolates, vinos, entre otros productos navideños para armar las canastas para las instituciones, la esposa del conyugue tiene contratado con 2 instituciones para armar 120 canastas para una institucion y para otra 80 canastas navideñas, el socio ayudara economicamente y tambien en todo lo referente al armado de canastas a su esposa, desde la compra de los productos y la distrubucion de los mismos, hasta la entrega de las canastas a las diferentes instituciones segun la lista que pidieron para el contenido de cada una de las canastas. El socio en esta ocasión apoyara economicamente y también en el armado de las diferentes canastas navideñas para las instituciones que su esposa hizo la contratación.

loans.use: El socio en esta ocasión apoyara economicamente y también en el armado de las diferentes canastas navideñas para las instituciones que su esposa hizo la contratación.

loans.name: Carolina

texts.es: Carolina se dedica a la venta de cosméticos, desde hace más de 5 años. La ubicación de su negocio es de manera ambulante, pues tiene una gran variedad de clientes que le han solicitado productos como perfumes, cremas, tratamientos, shampoo, reloj, ropa interior, polvos, pintura de uñas, pintura de labios entre otros. Desea seguir adelante con este negocio y al mismo tiempo mejorar el servicio al cliente. Carolina tiene dos hijos de 16 y 6 años respectivamente a quienes diariamente les enseña buenas cosas para la vida.
texts.en: Carolina has sold cosmetics for over five years. Her business is door-to-door, since she has a large variety of customers who request items such as perfumes, creams, treatments, shampoo, watches, underwear, powder, nail polish, and lipstick, among other items. She wants to keep moving forward with her business and also improve her customer service. Carolina has two children ages 6 and 16. She teaches them life lessons every day.

loans.use: to buy perfumes, creams, treatments, shampoo, watches, underwear, powder, nail polish, and lipstick, among other items.

loans.name: Nieves

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “PEROLNIYOC DE URUBAMBA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Urubamba, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Nieves; ella tiene 52 años de edad y es casada y tiene 5 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de comida, la socia también se dedica a la venta de artesanía ella lleva a lugares como Machupicchu y también vende maíz en el mercado de Urubamba, por medio de estos negocios la socia saca adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar el negocio de venta de comida, venta de maíz y venta de artesanía. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar maíz al por mayor y también para comprar artesanía y productos para cocinar como arroz, carne y pollo.
 
 La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
The borrower is a member of the communal bank “PEROLNIYOC DE URUBAMBA”, located in the district and province of Urubamba, in the department of Cuzco. 

The borrower is Señora Nieves. She is 52 years old and is married with 5 children. Her work varies from day to day, between her business selling food, selling handicrafts at tourist sites such as Machu Picchua, and selling maize in the market in Urubamba. She has brought up her children on what she earns from these businesses, and wishes to expand all three. She is seeking the loan to buy maize, in bulk, and also to buy handicrafts and ingredients for cooking, such as rice, meat and chicken. 

She is happy at being granted a loan and vows to make her repayments on time.

loans.use: To buy maize in bulk, and also to buy crafts and ingredients for cooking such as rice, meat and chicken.

loans.name: Alejandro Jesus

texts.es:
Alejandro es un joven soltero de 19 años de edad, el se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza, (perfume, jabón) ademas se dedica al negocio del horneo de pollo, pavo, entre otros, esta ocupación es secundaria la cual aprendió de su señor Padre que le enseño este oficio, Alejando es un hombre trabajador, empeñoso y muy luchador con muchas ganas de salir adelante,  lleva en el negocio de productos de belleza desde el año 2008 gana semanalmente S/ 180 soles, con el préstamo que recibirá gracias a Kiva lo invertirá para ampliar el pequeño negocio que tiene para que pueda hornear aves y otros, con la construcción de un pequeño horno artesanal el cual le brindara las facilidades y por supuesto mucho mas ingresos, uno de sus sueños es estudiar una carrera, para que llegue  a ser un gran profesional y con el tiempo tener un mejor tipo de vida, su asesor cree que es un buen cliente y que si pagara su crédito puntualmente
Alejandro vive y trabaja en Chincha, or Chincha Alta, Perú. Chincha is named after its early the Chincha culture, celebrated for their advanced knowledge of agricultural and their maritime prowess. Today Chincha is an incredible mix of cultures, with a large Afro-Peruvian population, remnants of an indigenous path, and influences from the Spanish empire. The city, along with others near the Pacific coast, was damaged during the 2001 and 2007 Peru earthquakes, but has preserved as it has for much of its history.
texts.en: Alejandro is a young, single, 19-year-old man who sells beauty products (perfumes and soap). He also works oven baking chicken, turkey, etc. This is a secondary occupation which he learned from his father. Alejandro is a hard-working, determined, very tenacious man who has a great desire to get ahead in life. He has been working in his beauty products business since 2008 and earns 180 soles a week. He will invest the loan that he receives thanks to Kiva in expanding his small business, so that he can bake birds and other things, by building a small horno artesanal (literally: an artisan's oven - these are most often made from clay, brick or stone) which will provide him with facilities and, of course, a lot more income. One of Alejandro's dreams is to study for a degree so that he can become a great professional and, over time, enjoy a better type of life. His loan officer believes him to be a good client and believes that he will make his loan repayments on time. Alejandro lives and works in Chinca, Chincha Alta, Perú. Chincha is named after its early Chincha culture. The Chincha were celebrated for their advanced knowledge of agriculture and their maritime prowess. Today Chincha is an incredible mix of cultures, with a large Afro-Peruvian population, indigenous people and influences from the Spanish empire. The city, along with others near the Pacific coast, was damaged during the 2001 and 2007 Peru earthquakes but it has been preserved as it has been for much of its history.

loans.use: to build an oven

loans.name: Pascal

texts.en: Pascal is 29 years old and married with one child. His wife is a teacher. He owns a general store, which he has been running for 7 years. Pascal would like a loan to buy items such as sugar, rice, and potatoes to sell in his store. Any profits will be used to create savings for his family.

loans.use: To buy items such as sugar, rice, and potatoes to sell in his store.

loans.name: Mwashamba

texts.en:
Mwashamba is a 31-year-old married woman with three children. Two of the children attend school and one is too young. Her husband is a businessman who contributes to the provision of basic family needs. Mwashamba lives in a rental house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Mwashamba has operated a retail shop for the past two years, with her neighbors as her customers. With the loan of KES 40,000 she wants to purchase stocks of sugar, rice and cereals for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial assistance to expand her business, which is her dream.

loans.use: To purchase stocks of sugar, rice and cereals for resale.

loans.name: Jacqueline Lissette

texts.es: La Señora Jacqueline trabaja en su pulpería, se inició con pequeñas ganancias que había ahorrado, pues es una persona muy trabajadora y responsable.
